analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu sabbasas viññāṇañca āyatanam samatikkamma na atthi kiñci iti ākiñcaññāyatanam upasampajja viharati
translated: Here, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu, with the complete surmounting of the base of the infinity of consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing,’ enters and dwells in the base of nothingness.

original: So yadeva tattha hoti vedanāgataṁ saññāgataṁ saṅkhāragataṁ viññāṇagataṁ, te dhamme🔽aniccato dukkhato rogato gaṇḍato sallato aghato ābādhato parato palokato suññato
analyzed: so yat eva tattha hoti vedanā gatam saññā gatam saṅkhāra gatam viññāṇa gata te dhamme  aniccataḥ dukkhataḥ rogataḥ gaṇḍataḥ sallataḥ aghataḥ ābādhataḥ paratas palokataḥ suññataḥ
translated: Whatever there is of feeling, perception, formations, and consciousness,

original: anattato samanupassati.
analyzed: anattataḥ samanupassati
translated: he regards those states as impermanent, as suffering, as a disease, as a tumour, as a barb, as a calamity, as an affliction, as alien, as disintegrating, as void, as not self.

original: So tehi dhammehi cittaṁ paṭivāpeti.
analyzed: saḥ tehi dhammehi cittam paṭivāpeti
translated: He turns his mind away from those states.

original: So tehi dhammehi cittaṁ paṭivāpetvā amatāya dhātuyā cittaṁ upasaṁharati:
analyzed: saḥ tehi dhammehi cittam paṭivāpetvā amatāya dhātuyā cittam upasaharati
translated: Having turned his mind away from those states, he resolves his mind on the deathless element thus:

original: ‘etaṁ santaṁ etaṁ paṇītaṁ yadidaṁ sabbasaṅkhārasamatho sabbūpadhipaṭinissaggo taṇhākkhayo virāgo nirodho nibbānan’ti.
analyzed: etam santam etam paṇītam yat idam sabba saṅkhāra samatho sabba upadhi paṭinissaggo taṇhā kkhayaḥ virāgaḥ nirodhaḥ nibbānam ti
translated: ‘This is the peaceful, this is the sublime, that is, the stilling of all formations, the relinquishing of all attachments, the destruction of craving, dispassion, cessation, Nibbāna.’

original: So tattha ṭhito āsavānaṁ khayaṁ pāpuṇāti.
analyzed: saḥ tattha ṭhitaḥ āsavānam khayam pāpuṇāti
translated: Abiding thus, he attains the destruction of the taints.

original: No ce āsavānaṁ khayaṁ pāpuṇāti, teneva dhammarāgena tāya dhammanandiyā pañcannaṁ orambhāgiyānaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā opapātiko hoti tattha parinibbāyī anāvattidhammo tasmā lokā.
analyzed: no ce āsavānam khayam pāpuṇāti tena iva dhamma rāgena tāya dhamma nandiyā pañcannam orambhāgiyānam sayojanānam parikkhayā opapātikaḥ hoti tattha parinibbāyī an āvatti dhammo tasmā lokā
translated: But if he does not attain the destruction of the taints, then because of that desire for the Dhamma, that delight in the Dhamma, with the destruction of the five lower fetters he becomes one due to reappear spontaneously in the Pure Abodes and there attain final Nibbana without ever returning from that world.

original: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, issāso vā issāsantevāsī vā tiṇapurisarūpake vā mattikāpuñje
analyzed: seyyathā api bhikkhave issāsaḥ vā issāsa antevāsī vā tiṇa purisa rūpake vā mattikā puñje
translated: Just as a master fletcher or his apprentice, having made a bundle of fletched arrows or of arrow shafts,

original: vā yoggaṁ karitvā, so aparena samayena dūrepātī ca hoti akkhaṇavedhī ca mahato ca kāyassa padāletā;
analyzed: vā yoggam karitvā saḥ aparena samayena dūrepātī ca hoti akkhaṇa vedhī ca mahato ca kāyassa padāletā
translated: might after some time become one who can shoot far and can pierce a large target,

original: evamevaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṁ samatikkamma ‘natthi kiñcī’ti ākiñcaññāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: evam evam kho bhikkhave bhikkhu sabbasas viññāṇañca āyatanam samatikkamma na atthi kiñci iti ākiñcaññāyatanam upasampajja viharati
translated: so too, bhikkhus, having completely transcended the sphere of boundless consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing,’ a bhikkhu enters and dwells in the sphere of nothingness.

original: So yadeva tattha hoti vedanāgataṁ saññāgataṁ saṅkhāragataṁ viññāṇagataṁ, te dhamme🔽aniccato dukkhato rogato gaṇḍato sallato aghato ābādhato parato palokato suññato
analyzed: so yat eva tattha hoti vedanā gatam saññā gatam saṅkhāra gatam viññāṇa gata te dhamme  aniccataḥ dukkhataḥ rogataḥ gaṇḍataḥ sallataḥ aghataḥ ābādhataḥ paratas palokataḥ suññataḥ
translated: Whatever exists therein of material form, feeling, perception, formations, and consciousness,

original: anattato samanupassati.🔽So tehi dhammehi cittaṁ paṭivāpeti.
analyzed: anattataḥ samanupassati  saḥ tehi dhammehi cittam paṭivāpeti
translated: he sees those states as impermanent, as suffering, as a disease, as a tumour, as a barb, as a calamity, as an affliction, as alien, as disintegrating, as void, as not self.

original: So tehi dhammehi cittaṁ paṭivāpetvā amatāya dhātuyā cittaṁ upasaṁharati:
analyzed: saḥ tehi dhammehi cittam paṭivāpetvā amatāya dhātuyā cittam upasaharati
translated: He turns his mind away from those states and directs it towards the deathless element thus:🔽‘This is the peaceful, this is the sublime, that is, the stilling of all formations, the relinquishing of all acquisitions, the destruction of craving, dispassion, cessation, Nibbāna.’

original: ‘etaṁ santaṁ etaṁ paṇītaṁ yadidaṁ sabbasaṅkhārasamatho sabbūpadhipaṭinissaggo taṇhākkhayo virāgo nirodho nibbānan’ti.
analyzed: etam santam etam paṇītam yat idam sabba saṅkhāra samatho sabba upadhi paṭinissaggo taṇhā kkhayaḥ virāgaḥ nirodhaḥ nibbānam ti
translated: ‘This is peaceful, this is sublime, that is, equanimity.

original: So tattha ṭhito āsavānaṁ khayaṁ pāpuṇāti.
analyzed: saḥ tattha ṭhitaḥ āsavānam khayam pāpuṇāti
translated: “Abiding in that, he attains the destruction of the taints.

original: No ce āsavānaṁ khayaṁ pāpuṇāti, teneva dhammarāgena tāya dhammanandiyā pañcannaṁ orambhāgiyānaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā opapātiko hoti tattha parinibbāyī anāvattidhammo tasmā lokā.
analyzed: no ce āsavānam khayam pāpuṇāti tena iva dhamma rāgena tāya dhamma nandiyā pañcannam orambhāgiyānam sayojanānam parikkhayā opapātikaḥ hoti tattha parinibbāyī an āvatti dhammo tasmā lokā
translated: If he does not attain the destruction of the taints, then because of that desire and that delight, he is reborn in companionship with the devas who are Free from Perplexity.

original: ‘Ākiñcaññāyatanampāhaṁ, nissāya āsavānaṁ khayaṁ vadāmī’ti,
analyzed: ākiñcaññāyatanam pa āha nissāya āsavānam khayam vadāmi iti
translated: “‘I declare the destruction of the taints based on the base of nothingness.’

original: iti yaṁ taṁ vuttaṁ, idametaṁ paṭicca vuttaṁ.
analyzed: iti yam tam vutta idam etam paṭicca vutta
translated: “So it was with reference to this that it was said: ‘The penetration of the four noble truths is the fruit, the benefit of discernment.’

original: Iti kho, bhikkhave, yāvatā saññāsamāpatti tāvatā aññāpaṭivedho.
analyzed: iti kho bhikkhave yāvatā saññā samāpatti tāvatā aññā paṭivedho
translated: “Thus, bhikkhus, the extent to which there is a possibility for the attainment of concentration is the extent to which there is a possibility for the penetration of discernment.

original: Yāni ca kho imāni, bhikkhave, nissāya dve āyatanāni—
analyzed: yāni ca kho imāni bhikkhave nissāya dve āyatanāni
translated: “Now, bhikkhus, there are these two bases for giving effect to the higher virtue:

original: nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasamāpatti ca saññāvedayitanirodho ca, jhāyīhete, bhikkhave,
analyzed: nevasaññānāsaññāyatana samāpatti ca saññā vedayita nirodho ca jhāyī hete bhikkhave
translated: the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception and the base of the cessation of perception and feeling.

original: samāpattikusalehi samāpattivuṭṭhānakusalehi samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhahitvā sammā akkhātabbānīti vadāmī”ti.
analyzed: samāpatti kusalehi samāpatti vuṭṭhāna kusalehi samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhahitvā sammā akkhātabbāni iti vadāmi iti
translated: I say that they should be corrected by those skilled in attainment and by those skilled in emergence.”

original: Pañcamaṁ.
analyzed: pañcama
translated: The fifth section on the Sangha is finished.

original: Aṅguttara Nikāya 9.37
analyzed: aṅguttara nikāya
translated: The Book of the Elevens

original: 4. Mahāvagga
analyzed: mahāvagga
translated: The Great Chapter

original: Ānandasutta
analyzed: ānanda sutta
translated: With Ānanda

original: Ekaṁ samayaṁ āyasmā ānando kosambiyaṁ viharati ghositārāme.
analyzed: ekam samayam āyasmai ānandaḥ kosambiyam viharati ghosita ārāme
translated: One time the Venerable Ānanda was living at Kosambī in Ghosita’s Park.

original: Tatra kho āyasmā ānando bhikkhū āmantesi:
analyzed: tatra kho āyasman ānandaḥ bhikkhū āmantesi
translated: There the Venerable Ānanda addressed the bhikkhus thus:

original: “āvuso bhikkhave”ti.
analyzed: āvuso bhikkhave ti
translated: “Friends, bhikkhus.”

original: “Āvuso”ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmato ānandassa paccassosuṁ.
analyzed: āvuso ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmato ānandassa
translated: “Friend,” those bhikkhus replied.

original: Āyasmā ānando etadavoca:
analyzed: āyasmai ānandaḥ etat avoca
translated: The Venerable Ānanda said this:

original: “Acchariyaṁ, āvuso, abbhutaṁ, āvuso.🔽Yāvañcidaṁ tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena sambādhe okāsādhigamo
analyzed: acchariyaḥ āvuso abbhutaḥ āvuso  yāvat cidam tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena sambādhe okāsa adhigamaḥ
translated: “It is wonderful, friends, it is marvellous

original: anubuddho sattānaṁ visuddhiyā sokaparidevānaṁ samatikkamāya dukkhadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamāya
analyzed: anubuddhaḥ sattānam visuddhiyā soka paridevānam samatikkamāya dukkha domanassānaṃ atthaṅgamāya
translated: how the Blessed One, the Arahant, the Perfectly Enlightened One, who knows and sees, has discovered the crossing of the flood for the benefit of beings, for the purification of beings, for the deathlessness of beings,

original: ñāyassa adhigamāya nibbānassa sacchikiriyāya.
analyzed: ñāyassa adhigamāya nibbānassa sacchikiriyāya
translated: for the sake of heaven and escape.

original: Tadeva nāma cakkhuṁ bhavissati te rūpā tañcāyatanaṁ no paṭisaṁvedissati.
analyzed: tat eva nāma cakkhum bhavissati te rūpā tat ca āyatanam no paṭisavedissati
translated: That eye exists, those visible objects exist, but that base does not exist.

original: Tadeva nāma sotaṁ bhavissati te saddā tañcāyatanaṁ no paṭisaṁvedissati.🔽Tadeva nāma ghānaṁ bhavissati te gandhā tañcāyatanaṁ no paṭisaṁvedissati.
analyzed: tat eva nāma sotam bhavissati te saddāḥ tañca āyatanam no paṭisavedissati  tat eva nāma ghānam bhavissati te gandhā tat ca āyatanam no paṭisavedissati
translated: There will be the ear, there will be sounds, but one will not experience that sense base.🔽There will be the nose, there will be odours, but one will not experience that sense base.

original: Sāva nāma jivhā bhavissati te rasā tañcāyatanaṁ no paṭisaṁvedissati.
analyzed: sā ava nāma jivhā bhavissati te rasā tat ca āyatanam no paṭisavedissati
translated: There will be the tongue, there will be flavours, but one will not experience that sense base.

original: Sova nāma kāyo bhavissati te phoṭṭhabbā tañcāyatanaṁ no paṭisaṁvedissatī”ti.
analyzed: saḥ uva nāma kāyaḥ bhavissati te phoṭṭhabbā tat ca āyatanam no paṭisavedissati iti
translated: There will be the body, there will be tangible objects, but one will not experience that sense base.”

original: Evaṁ vutte, āyasmā udāyī āyasmantaṁ ānandaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: evam vutte āyasmā udāyī āyasmantam ānandam etat avoca
translated: When this was said, the venerable Udayi said to the venerable Ananda:

original: “saññīmeva nu kho, āvuso ānanda, tadāyatanaṁ no paṭisaṁvedeti udāhu asaññī”ti?
analyzed: saññīm eva nu khalu āvuso ānanda tat āyatanam no paṭisaveda iti udāhu asaññī iti
translated: “Friend Ananda, does one who experiences that sense base do so perceiving or not perceiving?”

original: “Saññīmeva kho, āvuso, tadāyatanaṁ no paṭisaṁvedeti, no asaññī”ti.
analyzed: saññīm eva kho āvuso tat āyatanam no paṭisavedeti no asaññī iti
translated: “Friend, one who experiences that sense base does so perceiving, not non-perceiving.”

original: “Kiṁsaññī panāvuso, tadāyatanaṁ no paṭisaṁvedetī”ti?
analyzed: kisaññī pana āvuso tat āyatanam no paṭisavedeti iti
translated: “But, friend, what does one perceive in experiencing that sense base?”

original: “Idhāvuso, bhikkhu, sabbaso rūpasaññānaṁ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṁ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṁ amanasikārā ‘ananto ākāso’ti ākāsānañcāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: idha āvuso bhikkhu sabbaso rūpa saññānam samatikkamā paṭigha saññānam atthaṅgamā nānatta saññānam amanasikārā anantaḥ ākāsaḥ ti ākāsānañcāyatanam upasampajja viharati
translated: “Here, friend, with the complete surmounting of perceptions of form, with the disappearance of perceptions of sensory impact, with non-attention to perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite,’ a bhikkhu enters and dwells in the base of the infinity of space.

original: Evaṁsaññīpi kho, āvuso, tadāyatanaṁ no paṭisaṁvedeti.
analyzed: evasaññī ipi kho āvuso tat āyatanam no paṭisaveda iti
translated: Though he has such a perception, he does not yet identify with it.

original: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṁ samatikkamma ‘anantaṁ viññāṇan’ti viññāṇañcāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: puna caparaḥ āvuso bhikkhu sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanam samatikkamma anantam viññāṇanti viññāṇañcāyatanam upasampajja viharati
translated: “Again, friend, by completely surmounting the base of the infinity of space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite,’ a bhikkhu enters and dwells in the base of the infinity of consciousness.

original: Evaṁsaññīpi kho, āvuso, tadāyatanaṁ no paṭisaṁvedeti.
analyzed: evasaññī ipi kho āvuso tat āyatanam no paṭisaveda iti
translated: Though he has such a perception, he does not yet identify with it.

original: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṁ samatikkamma ‘natthi kiñcī’ti ākiñcaññāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: puna caparaḥ āvuso bhikkhu sabbasas viññāṇañca āyatanam samatikkamma na atthi kiñci iti ākiñcaññāyatanam upasampajja viharati
translated: “Again, friend, by completely surmounting the base of the infinity of consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing,’ a bhikkhu enters and dwells in the base of nothingness.

original: Evaṁsaññīpi kho, āvuso, tadāyatanaṁ no paṭisaṁvedetīti.
analyzed: evasaññī ipi kho āvuso tat āyatanam no paṭisavedeti iti
translated: Though he has such a perception, he does not yet identify with it.”

original: Ekamidāhaṁ, āvuso, samayaṁ sākete viharāmi añjanavane migadāye.
analyzed: ekam id āha āvuso samayam sākete viharāmi añjana vane migadāye
translated: “On one occasion, friend, I was dwelling at Saketa in the Añjana Grove, in the deer park.

original: Atha kho, āvuso, jaṭilavāsikā bhikkhunī yenāhaṁ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā maṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṁ ṭhitā kho, āvuso, jaṭilavāsikā bhikkhunī maṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: atha kho āvuso jaṭilavāsikā bhikkhunī yena aham tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā mama abhivādetvā ekamantam aṭṭhāsi ekamantam ṭhitā kho āvuso jaṭilavāsikā bhikkhunī mam etat avoca
translated: Then the nun Jaṭilavāsikā came to me, bowed, stood downwind, and said:

original: ‘yāyaṁ, bhante ānanda, samādhi na cābhinato na cāpanato na ca sasaṅkhāraniggayhavāritagato,
analyzed: bhante ānanda samādhi na ca abhinataḥ na ca apanataḥ na ca sa saṅkhāra niggayha vārita gataḥ
translated: ‘Venerable Ānanda, this concentration is neither slack nor strained.

original: vimuttattā ṭhito, ṭhitattā santusito, santusitattā no paritassati.
analyzed: vimutta ttā ṭhitaḥ ṭhita ttā santusitaḥ santusita ttā no paritassati
translated: It’s settled internally, unified, and concentrated on a single object.

original: Ayaṁ, bhante ānanda, samādhi kiṁphalo vutto bhagavatā’ti?
analyzed: bhante ānanda samādhi kiphalaḥ vuttaḥ bhagavatā ati
translated: What is the fruit and benefit of this concentration?’

original: Evaṁ vutte, sohaṁ, āvuso, jaṭilavāsikaṁ bhikkhuniṁ etadavocaṁ:
analyzed: evam vutte saḥ ha āvuso jaṭilavāsikam bhikkhunim etat avoca
translated: When this was said, I replied to the nun Jaṭilavāsikā:

original: ‘yāyaṁ, bhagini, samādhi na cābhinato na cāpanato na ca sasaṅkhāraniggayhavāritagato,
analyzed: bhagini samādhi na ca abhinataḥ na ca apanataḥ na ca sa saṅkhāra niggayha vārita gataḥ
translated: ‘Sister, this concentration is neither slack nor strained.

original: vimuttattā ṭhito, ṭhitattā santusito, santusitattā no paritassati.
analyzed: vimutta ttā ṭhitaḥ ṭhita ttā santusitaḥ santusita ttā no paritassati
translated: It’s settled internally, unified, and concentrated on a single object.

original: Ayaṁ, bhagini, samādhi aññāphalo vutto bhagavatā’ti.
analyzed: bhagini samādhi aññāphalo vuttaḥ bhagavatā ati
translated: The Buddha has declared the fruit and benefit of this concentration to be knowledge and vision.’

original: Evaṁsaññīpi kho, āvuso, tadāyatanaṁ no paṭisaṁvedetī”ti.
analyzed: evasaññī ipi kho āvuso tat āyatanam no paṭisavedeti iti
translated: But one who perceives thus does not feel that base internally.”🔽The sixth section on the base of infinite consciousness is finished.

original: Chaṭṭhaṁ.🔽Aṅguttara Nikāya 9.38
analyzed: chaṭṭha  aṅguttara nikāya
translated: The Book of the Sixes

original: 4. Mahāvagga
analyzed: mahāvagga
translated: The Greater Division

original: Lokāyatikasutta
analyzed: lokāyatika sutta
translated: With the Logicians

original: Atha kho dve lokāyatikā brāhmaṇā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṁsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṁ sammodiṁsu.
analyzed: atha khalu dve lokāyatikāḥ brāhmaṇāḥ yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkamisu upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhim sammodisu
translated: Then two brahmin logicians went to the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him.

original: Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu. Ekamantaṁ nisinnā kho te brāhmaṇā bhagavantaṁ etadavocuṁ:
analyzed: sammodanīyam katham sāraṇīyam vītisāretvā ekamantam nisīdisu ekamantam nisinnāḥ kho te brāhmaṇāḥ bhagavantam etat avocuḥ
translated: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they sat down to one side and said to him:

original: “Pūraṇo, bho gotama, kassapo sabbaññū sabbadassāvī aparisesaṁ ñāṇadassanaṁ paṭijānāti:
analyzed: pūraṇaḥ bho gotama kassapaḥ sabbaññū sabba dassāvī aparisesam ñāṇa dassanam paṭijānāti
translated: “Master Gotama, Pūraṇa Kassapa claims to be all-knowing and all-seeing and to have all-embracing knowledge and vision.🔽He says:

original: ‘carato ca me tiṭṭhato ca suttassa ca jāgarassa ca satataṁ samitaṁ ñāṇadassanaṁ paccupaṭṭhitan’ti.
analyzed: carataḥ ca me tiṭṭhataḥ ca suttassa ca jāgarassa ca satatam samitam ñāṇa dassanam paccupaṭṭhitanti
translated: ‘Whether I am walking, standing, sleeping, or awake, knowledge and vision are constantly and continuously present to me.’

original: So evamāha:
analyzed: sā u evam āha
translated: He says:

original: ‘ahaṁ anantena ñāṇena anantaṁ lokaṁ jānaṁ passaṁ viharāmī’ti.
analyzed: aham anantena ñāṇena anantam lokam jānam passam viharāmi iti
translated: ‘I live knowing and seeing the infinite world.’

original: Ayampi, bho gotama, nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto sabbaññū sabbadassāvī aparisesaṁ ñāṇadassanaṁ paṭijānāti:
analyzed: ayam pi bho gotama nigaṇṭhaḥ nāṭa putto sabbaññū sabba dassāvī aparisesam ñāṇa dassanam paṭijānāti
translated: This Nigaṇṭha Nāṭaputta claims to be all-knowing and all-seeing and to have all-embracing knowledge and vision.

original: ‘carato ca me tiṭṭhato ca suttassa ca jāgarassa ca satataṁ samitaṁ ñāṇadassanaṁ paccupaṭṭhitan’ti.
analyzed: carataḥ ca me tiṭṭhataḥ ca suttassa ca jāgarassa ca satatam samitam ñāṇa dassanam paccupaṭṭhitanti
translated: ‘Whether I’m walking, standing, asleep, or awake, knowledge and vision are constantly present to me.’

original: So evamāha:
analyzed: sā u evam āha
translated: He says:

original: ‘ahaṁ anantena ñāṇena anantaṁ lokaṁ jānaṁ passaṁ viharāmī’ti.
analyzed: aham anantena ñāṇena anantam lokam jānam passam viharāmi iti
translated: ‘I live knowing and seeing an endless world.’

original: Imesaṁ, bho gotama, ubhinnaṁ ñāṇavādānaṁ ubhinnaṁ aññamaññaṁ vipaccanīkavādānaṁ ko saccaṁ āha ko musā”ti?
analyzed: bho gotama ubhinnam ñāṇa vādānam ubhinnam aññamaññam vipaccanīka vādānam kaḥ saccam āha kaḥ musā ati
translated: Between these two, who speaks the truth and who lies?”

original: “Alaṁ, brāhmaṇā.
analyzed: ala brāhmaṇā
translated: “Enough, brahmin.

original: Tiṭṭhatetaṁ:
analyzed: tiṭṭhata ita
translated: Let that be.

original: ‘imesaṁ ubhinnaṁ ñāṇavādānaṁ ubhinnaṁ aññamaññaṁ vipaccanīkavādānaṁ ko saccaṁ āha ko musā’ti.
analyzed: imesam ubhinnam ñāṇa vādānam ubhinnam aññamaññam vipaccanīka vādānam kaḥ saccam āha kaḥ musā iti
translated: ‘Between these two, who speaks the truth and who lies?’

original: Dhammaṁ vo, brāhmaṇā, desessāmi,
analyzed: dhammam vaḥ brāhmaṇāḥ desessāmi
translated: I will teach you the Dhamma.

original: taṁ suṇātha, sādhukaṁ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
analyzed: tam suṇātha sādhukam manasi karotha bhāsissāmi iti
translated: Listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”

original: “Evaṁ, bho”ti kho te brāhmaṇā bhagavato paccassosuṁ.
analyzed: eva bhoti kho te brāhmaṇāḥ bhagavato paccassosu
translated: “Yes, sir,” they replied.

original: Bhagavā etadavoca:
analyzed: bhagavān etat avoca
translated: The Buddha said this:

original: “Seyyathāpi, brāhmaṇā, cattāro purisā catuddisā ṭhitā paramena javena ca samannāgatā paramena ca padavītihārena.
analyzed: sā iyyathā api brāhmaṇā cattāro purisā catuddisā ṭhitā paramena javena ca samannāgatā paramena ca padavī tihārena
translated: “Suppose there were four men standing at the four directions, each with a bow and arrow.

original: Te evarūpena javena samannāgatā assu, seyyathāpi nāma daḷhadhammā dhanuggaho sikkhito katahattho katūpāsano lahukena asanena appakasirena tiriyaṁ tālacchāyaṁ atipāteyya;
analyzed: te evarūpena javena samannāgatāḥ assu seyyathā api nāma daḷhadhammā dhanuggahaḥ sikkhitaḥ kata hatthaḥ kata upāsanaḥ lahukena asanena appa kasirena tiriyam tāla chāyam atipāteyya
translated: They would have such speed, such a pace, such a stride that they would go a thousand leagues in an instant, a hundred leagues in an instant, ten leagues in an instant, five leagues in an instant, four leagues in an instant, three leagues in an instant, two leagues in an instant, one league in an instant, half a league in an instant, a league in the morning and a league in the afternoon, and they would go a thousand leagues in a day.

original: evarūpena ca padavītihārena, seyyathāpi nāma puratthimā samuddā pacchimo samuddo
analyzed: evarūpena ca padavī tihārena sā iyyathā api nāma puratthimā samuddā pacchimaḥ samuddo
translated: They would have such a pace, such a stride that they would go from the eastern ocean to the western ocean in a day.

original: atha puratthimāya disāya ṭhito puriso evaṁ vadeyya:
analyzed: atha puratthimāya disāya ṭhitaḥ purisaḥ evam vadeyya
translated: Then a man standing in the east would say:

original: ‘ahaṁ gamanena lokassa antaṁ pāpuṇissāmī’ti.
analyzed: aham gamanena lokassa antam pāpuṇissāmi iti
translated: ‘I will go by foot to the end of the world.’

original: So aññatreva asitapītakhāyitasāyitā aññatra uccārapassāvakammā aññatra niddākilamathapaṭivinodanā
analyzed: so aññatra iva asita pīta khāyita sāyitā aññatra uccāra passāva kammā aññatra niddā kilamatha paṭivinodanā
translated: He would go for a hundred years, a hundred and fifty years, two hundred years,🔽and he would die along the way without having reached the end of the world.🔽Then a man standing in the west would say:

original: vassasatāyuko vassasatajīvī vassasataṁ gantvā appatvāva lokassa antaṁ antarā kālaṁ kareyya.
analyzed: vassa sata āyukaḥ vassa sata jīvī vassa satam gantvā ap patvā ava lokassa antam antarā kālam kareyya
translated: ‘I will go by foot to the end of the world.’

original: Atha pacchimāya disāya …pe…
analyzed: atha pacchimāya disāya pe
translated: Then a man standing in the north would say:

original: atha uttarāya disāya …
analyzed: atha uttarāya disāya
translated: ‘I will go by foot to the end of the world.’

original: atha dakkhiṇāya disāya ṭhito puriso evaṁ vadeyya:
analyzed: atha dakkhiṇāya disāya ṭhitaḥ purisaḥ evam vadeyya
translated: Then a man standing in the south would say:

original: ‘ahaṁ gamanena lokassa antaṁ pāpuṇissāmī’ti.
analyzed: aham gamanena lokassa antam pāpuṇissāmi iti
translated: ‘I will go by foot to the end of the world.’

original: So aññatreva asitapītakhāyitasāyitā aññatra uccārapassāvakammā aññatra niddākilamathapaṭivinodanā
analyzed: so aññatra iva asita pīta khāyita sāyitā aññatra uccāra passāva kammā aññatra niddā kilamatha paṭivinodanā
translated: He would go for a hundred years, a hundred generations of Brahma’s people, without finding the end of the world.

original: vassasatāyuko vassasatajīvī vassasataṁ gantvā appatvāva lokassa antaṁ antarā kālaṁ kareyya.
analyzed: vassa sata āyukaḥ vassa sata jīvī vassa satam gantvā ap patvā ava lokassa antam antarā kālam kareyya
translated: But before he found the end of the world, he would die along the way.

original: Taṁ kissa hetu?🔽Nāhaṁ, brāhmaṇā, evarūpāya sandhāvanikāya lokassa antaṁ ñāteyyaṁ daṭṭheyyaṁ patteyyanti vadāmi.
analyzed: tam kim sa hetu  na aha brāhmaṇāḥ evarūpāya sandhāvanikāya lokassa antam ñāteyyam daṭṭheyyam patteyyam ti vadāmi
translated: And why is that?🔽Because, brahmin, I say that the end of the world cannot be found by travelling.

original: Na cāhaṁ, brāhmaṇā, appatvāva lokassa antaṁ dukkhassa antakiriyaṁ vadāmi.
analyzed: na ca āha brāhmaṇāḥ a patvā ava lokassa antam dukkhassa anta kiriyam vadāmi
translated: And I say that the end of the world cannot be reached by going.

original: Pañcime, brāhmaṇā, kāmaguṇā ariyassa vinaye lokoti vuccati.
analyzed: pañcime brāhmaṇā kāma guṇā ariyassa vinaye loko ti vuccati
translated: But, brahmin, in the Noble One’s Discipline, the world is five-holding-aggregates.

original: Katame pañca?🔽Cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṁhitā rajanīyā;🔽sotaviññeyyā saddā …pe…🔽ghānaviññeyyā gandhā …🔽jivhāviññeyyā rasā …
analyzed: katame pañca  cakkhu viññeyyā rūpā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piya rūpā kāma upasahitā rajanīyā  sota viññeyyā saddāḥ pe  ghāna viññeyyāḥ gandhāḥ  jivhā viññeyyāḥ rasāḥ
translated: What five?

original: kāyaviññeyyā phoṭṭhabbā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṁhitā rajanīyā;
analyzed: kāya viññeyyā phoṭṭhabbā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piya rūpā kāma upasahitā rajanīyā
translated: The form-holding-aggregate, the feeling-holding-aggregate, the perception-holding-aggregate, the mental-formation-holding-aggregate, the consciousness-holding-aggregate.🔽These, brahmin, are the five holding-aggregates in the Noble One’s Discipline that are called the world.

original: ime kho, brāhmaṇā, pañca kāmaguṇā ariyassa vinaye lokoti vuccati.
analyzed: ime kho brāhmaṇā pañca kāmaguṇā ariyassa vinaye loko ti vuccati
translated: These, brahmins, are the five kinds of sensual pleasure that are called the world in the Noble One’s discipline.

original: Idha, brāhmaṇā, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṁ savicāraṁ vivekajaṁ pītisukhaṁ paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: idha brāhmaṇāḥ bhikkhu vivicca iva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi sa vitakkam sa vicāram viveka jam pīti sukham paṭhamam jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: “Here, brahmins, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unwholesome states, a bhikkhu enters upon and abides in the first jhana, which is accompanied by applied and sustained thought, with rapture and pleasure born of seclusion.

original: Ayaṁ vuccati, brāhmaṇā, ‘bhikkhu lokassa antamāgamma, lokassa ante viharati’.
analyzed: ayam vuccati brāhmaṇāḥ bhikkhu lokassa antam āgamma lokassa ante viharati
translated: This is called a bhikkhu who has reached the end of the world and abides at the end of the world.

original: Tamaññe evamāhaṁsu:
analyzed: tam aññe evam āhasu
translated: Others say of him:

original: ‘ayampi lokapariyāpanno, ayampi anissaṭo lokamhā’ti.
analyzed: ayam pi loka pariyāpannaḥ ayam pi anissaṭaḥ lokamhā ati
translated: ‘He is included in the world; he has not emerged from the world.’

original: Ahampi hi, brāhmaṇā, evaṁ vadāmi:
analyzed: aham api hi brāhmaṇāḥ evam vadāmi
translated: And I too say of him:

original: ‘ayampi lokapariyāpanno, ayampi anissaṭo lokamhā’ti.
analyzed: ayam pi loka pariyāpannaḥ ayam pi anissaṭaḥ lokamhā ati
translated: ‘He is included in the world; he has not emerged from the world.’

original: Puna caparaṁ, brāhmaṇā, bhikkhu vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā …pe… dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ …
analyzed: puna capara brāhmaṇāḥ vitakka vicārānaṃ vūpasamā pe dutiyam jhānaṃ
translated: “Again, brahmins, with the stilling of applied and sustained thought, a bhikkhu enters upon and abides in the second jhana…

original: tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ …🔽catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: tatiyam jhānam  catuttham jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: the third jhana…🔽the fourth jhana, which has neither-pain-nor-pleasure and purity of mindfulness due to equanimity.

original: Ayaṁ vuccati, brāhmaṇā, ‘bhikkhu lokassa antamāgamma lokassa ante viharati’.
analyzed: ayam vuccati brāhmaṇāḥ bhikkhu lokassa antam āgamma lokassa ante viharati
translated: This is called a bhikkhu who has reached the end of the world and abides at the end of the world.

original: Tamaññe evamāhaṁsu:
analyzed: tam aññe evam āhasu
translated: Others say of him:

original: ‘ayampi lokapariyāpanno, ayampi anissaṭo lokamhā’ti.
analyzed: ayam pi loka pariyāpannaḥ ayam pi anissaṭaḥ lokamhā ati
translated: ‘This is included in the world, it has not escaped from the world.’

original: Ahampi hi, brāhmaṇā, evaṁ vadāmi:
analyzed: aham api hi brāhmaṇāḥ evam vadāmi
translated: I too say this:

original: ‘ayampi lokapariyāpanno, ayampi anissaṭo lokamhā’ti.
analyzed: ayam pi loka pariyāpannaḥ ayam pi anissaṭaḥ lokamhā ati
translated: ‘This is included in the world, it has not escaped from the world.’

original: Puna caparaṁ, brāhmaṇā, bhikkhu sabbaso rūpasaññānaṁ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṁ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṁ amanasikārā ‘ananto ākāso’ti ākāsānañcāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: puna capara brāhmaṇāḥ bhikkhu sabbaso rūpa saññānam samatikkamā paṭigha saññānam atthaṅgamā nānatta saññānam amanasikārā anantaḥ ākāsaḥ ti ākāsānañcāyatanam upasampajja viharati
translated: “Again, with the complete surmounting of perceptions of form, with the disappearance of perceptions of sensory impact, with non-attention to perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite,’ a bhikkhu enters and dwells in the base of the infinity of space.

original: Ayaṁ vuccati, brāhmaṇā, ‘bhikkhu lokassa antamāgamma lokassa ante viharati’.
analyzed: ayam vuccati brāhmaṇāḥ bhikkhu lokassa antam āgamma lokassa ante viharati
translated: This is called a bhikkhu who has reached the end of the world, who has crossed over attachment to the world.

original: Tamaññe evamāhaṁsu:
analyzed: tam aññe evam āhasu
translated: Others say of him:

original: ‘ayampi lokapariyāpanno, ayampi anissaṭo lokamhā’ti.
analyzed: ayam pi loka pariyāpannaḥ ayam pi anissaṭaḥ lokamhā ati
translated: ‘This is included in the world, it has not escaped from the world.’

original: Ahampi hi, brāhmaṇā, evaṁ vadāmi:
analyzed: aham api hi brāhmaṇāḥ evam vadāmi
translated: I too say this:

original: ‘ayampi lokapariyāpanno, ayampi anissaṭo lokamhā’ti.
analyzed: ayam pi loka pariyāpannaḥ ayam pi anissaṭaḥ lokamhā ati
translated: ‘This is included in the world, it has not escaped from the world.’

original: Puna caparaṁ, brāhmaṇā, bhikkhu sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṁ samatikkamma ‘anantaṁ viññāṇan’ti viññāṇañcāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati …pe…
analyzed: puna capara brāhmaṇāḥ bhikkhu sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanam samatikkamma anantam viññāṇanti viññāṇañcāyatanam upasampajja viharati pe
translated: “Again, with the complete surmounting of the base of the infinity of space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite,’ a bhikkhu enters and dwells in the base of the infinity of consciousness. …

original: sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṁ samatikkamma ‘natthi kiñcī’ti ākiñcaññāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati …pe…
analyzed: sabbaso viññāṇañca āyatanam samatikkamma na atthi kiñci iti ākiñcaññāyatanam upasampajja viharati pe
translated: He completely surmounts the base of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing.’ He enters and remains in the base of nothingness. …

original: sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanaṁ samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanam samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanam upasampajja viharati
translated: He completely surmounts the base of nothingness, and he enters and remains in the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.

original: Ayaṁ vuccati, brāhmaṇā, ‘bhikkhu lokassa antamāgamma lokassa ante viharati’.
analyzed: ayam vuccati brāhmaṇāḥ bhikkhu lokassa antam āgamma lokassa ante viharati
translated: This is called a monk who has reached the end of the world and dwells at the end of the world.

original: Tamaññe evamāhaṁsu:
analyzed: tam aññe evam āhasu
translated: Others say of him:

original: ‘ayampi lokapariyāpanno, ayampi anissaṭo lokamhā’ti.
analyzed: ayam pi loka pariyāpannaḥ ayam pi anissaṭaḥ lokamhā ati
translated: ‘He is included in the world and has not escaped from the world.’

original: Ahampi hi, brāhmaṇā, evaṁ vadāmi:
analyzed: aham api hi brāhmaṇāḥ evam vadāmi
translated: I too say of him:

original: ‘ayampi lokapariyāpanno, ayampi anissaṭo lokamhā’ti.
analyzed: ayam pi loka pariyāpannaḥ ayam pi anissaṭaḥ lokamhā ati
translated: ‘He is included in the world and has not escaped from the world.’

original: Puna caparaṁ, brāhmaṇā, bhikkhu sabbaso nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṁ samatikkamma saññāvedayitanirodhaṁ upasampajja viharati, paññāya cassa disvā āsavā parikkhīṇā honti.
analyzed: puna capara brāhmaṇāḥ bhikkhu sabbasas nevasaññānāsaññāyatanam samatikkamma saññā vedayita nirodham upasampajja viharati paññāya cassa disvā āsavā parikkhīṇāḥ honti
translated: “Again, a monk, completely surmounting the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception, enters and remains in the cessation of perception and feeling. With the destruction of the taints, he realizes for himself with direct knowledge, in this very life, the taintless liberation of mind, liberation by wisdom, and having entered upon it, he dwells in it.

original: Ayaṁ vuccati, brāhmaṇā, ‘bhikkhu lokassa antamāgamma lokassa ante viharati tiṇṇo loke visattikan’”ti.
analyzed: ayam vuccati brāhmaṇāḥ bhikkhu lokassa antam āgamma lokassa ante viharati tiṇṇaḥ loke visattikanti
translated: This is called a monk who has reached the end of the world and dwells at the end of the world, having crossed over attachment to the world.”

original: Sattamaṁ.
analyzed: sattama
translated: So said the Blessed One.🔽Having said this, the One Well-Gone, the Teacher, further said this:

original: Aṅguttara Nikāya 9.39
analyzed: aṅguttara nikāya
translated: The Numerical Discourses of the Buddha 9.39🔽

original: 4. Mahāvagga
analyzed: mahāvagga
translated: Numbered Discourses The Greater Section

original: Devāsurasaṅgāmasutta
analyzed: devāsurasaṅgāmasutta
translated: With the Gods and Demons

original: “Bhūtapubbaṁ, bhikkhave, devāsurasaṅgāmo samupabyūḷho ahosi.
analyzed: bhūta pubba bhikkhave deva asura saṅgāmaḥ samupabyūḷhaḥ ahosi
translated: “Once upon a time, monks, a battle was evenly matched between the gods and the demons.

original: Tasmiṁ kho pana, bhikkhave, saṅgāme asurā jiniṁsu, devā parājayiṁsu.
analyzed: tasmin kho pana bhikkhave saṅgāme asurāḥ devā parājayisu
translated: In that battle the demons won and the gods were defeated.

original: Parājitā ca, bhikkhave, devā apayiṁsuyeva uttarenābhimukhā, abhiyiṁsu asurā.
analyzed: parājitā ca bhikkhave devāḥ uttarena abhimukhāḥ abhiyisu asurāḥ
translated: And the defeated gods fled north, while the demons pursued them.

original: Atha kho, bhikkhave, devānaṁ etadahosi:
analyzed: atha kho bhikkhave devānam etat ahosi
translated: Then the gods thought,

original: ‘abhiyanteva kho asurā.
analyzed: abhiyantā iva khalu asurā
translated: ‘The demons are pursuing us.

original: Yannūna mayaṁ dutiyampi asurehi saṅgāmeyyāmā’ti.🔽Dutiyampi kho, bhikkhave, devā asurehi saṅgāmesuṁ.
analyzed: yat nūna mayam dutiyam pi asurehi saṅgāmeyyāma ati  dutiyam pi kho bhikkhave devāḥ asurehi saṅgāmesu
translated: Let us fight the demons a second time.’🔽And a second time the gods fought the demons.

original: Dutiyampi kho, bhikkhave, asurāva jiniṁsu, devā parājayiṁsu.
analyzed: dutiyam pi kho bhikkhave asurāva devā parājayisu
translated: And a second time the demons won and the gods were defeated.

original: Parājitā ca, bhikkhave, devā apayiṁsuyeva uttarenābhimukhā, abhiyiṁsu asurā.
analyzed: parājitā ca bhikkhave devāḥ uttarena abhimukhāḥ abhiyisu asurāḥ
translated: And the defeated gods fled north, while the demons pursued them.

original: Atha kho, bhikkhave, devānaṁ etadahosi:
analyzed: atha kho bhikkhave devānam etat ahosi
translated: Then the gods thought,

original: ‘abhiyanteva kho asurā.
analyzed: abhiyantā iva khalu asurā
translated: ‘The demons are pursuing us.

original: Yannūna mayaṁ tatiyampi asurehi saṅgāmeyyāmā’ti.
analyzed: yat nūna mayam tatiyam pi asurehi saṅgāma iyyāma ati
translated: Let us fight the demons a third time.’

original: Tatiyampi kho, bhikkhave, devā asurehi saṅgāmesuṁ.🔽Tatiyampi kho, bhikkhave, asurāva jiniṁsu, devā parājayiṁsu.
analyzed: tatiyam pi kho bhikkhave devāḥ asurehi saṅgāmesu  tatiyam pi kho bhikkhave asurāva devā parājayisu
translated: And a third time the gods and the asuras went into battle.

original: Parājitā ca, bhikkhave, devā bhītā devapuraṁyeva pavisiṁsu.
analyzed: parājitāḥ ca bhikkhave devāḥ bhītāḥ deva purayā iva pavisisu
translated: And a third time the asuras were victorious, and the gods were defeated.

original: Devapuragatānañca pana, bhikkhave, devānaṁ etadahosi:🔽‘bhīruttānagatena kho dāni mayaṁ etarahi attanā viharāma akaraṇīyā asurehī’ti.🔽Asurānampi, bhikkhave, etadahosi:
analyzed: deva pura gatānam ca pana bhikkhave devānam etat ahosi  bhīru ttāna gatena khalu dāni mayam etarahi attanā viharāma a karaṇīyāḥ asurehi iti  asurānam pi bhikkhave etat ahosi
translated: And the defeated gods, in fear, entered the city of the gods.🔽And the gods thought, ‘Now we live in fear, and the asuras have no fear of us.’

original: ‘bhīruttānagatena kho dāni devā etarahi attanā viharanti akaraṇīyā amhehī’ti.🔽Bhūtapubbaṁ, bhikkhave, devāsurasaṅgāmo samupabyūḷho ahosi.
analyzed: bhīru ttāna gatena kho dāni devāḥ etarahi attanā viharanti a karaṇīyāḥ amhehi iti  bhūta pubba bhikkhave deva asura saṅgāmaḥ samupabyūḷhaḥ ahosi
translated: And the asuras thought, ‘Now the gods live in fear, and we have no fear of them.’

original: Tasmiṁ kho pana, bhikkhave, saṅgāme devā jiniṁsu, asurā parājayiṁsu.
analyzed: tasmin kho pana bhikkhave saṅgāme devāḥ jinisu asurā parājayisu
translated: Once upon a time, monks, the gods and the asuras went into battle.🔽And in that battle the gods were victorious, while the asuras were defeated.

original: Parājitā ca, bhikkhave, asurā apayiṁsuyeva dakkhiṇenābhimukhā, abhiyiṁsu devā.🔽Atha kho, bhikkhave, asurānaṁ etadahosi:
analyzed: parājitā ca bhikkhave asurāḥ dakkhiṇena abhimukhāḥ devā  atha kho bhikkhave asurānam etat ahosi
translated: And the defeated asuras fled to the south, while the gods pursued them.

original: ‘abhiyanteva kho devā.
analyzed: abhiyantā iva khalu devā
translated: And the asuras thought, ‘The gods are pursuing us.

original: Yannūna mayaṁ dutiyampi devehi saṅgāmeyyāmā’ti.🔽Dutiyampi kho, bhikkhave, asurā devehi saṅgāmesuṁ.
analyzed: yat nūna mayam dutiyam pi devehi saṅgāmeyyāma ati  dutiyam pi kho bhikkhave asurāḥ devehi saṅgāmesu
translated: Let’s fight the gods a second time.’🔽And a second time the asuras fought with the gods.

original: Dutiyampi kho, bhikkhave, devā jiniṁsu, asurā parājayiṁsu.
analyzed: dutiyam pi kho bhikkhave devā jinisu asurā parājayisu
translated: And a second time the gods won and the asuras lost.

original: Parājitā ca, bhikkhave, asurā apayiṁsuyeva dakkhiṇenābhimukhā, abhiyiṁsu devā.🔽Atha kho, bhikkhave, asurānaṁ etadahosi:
analyzed: parājitā ca bhikkhave asurāḥ dakkhiṇena abhimukhāḥ devā  atha kho bhikkhave asurānam etat ahosi
translated: And the defeated asuras fled to the south, while the gods pursued them.

original: ‘abhiyanteva kho devā.
analyzed: abhiyantā iva khalu devā
translated: Then the asuras thought, ‘The gods are pursuing us.

original: Yannūna mayaṁ tatiyampi devehi saṅgāmeyyāmā’ti.🔽Tatiyampi kho, bhikkhave, asurā devehi saṅgāmesuṁ.
analyzed: yat nūna mayam tatiyam pi devehi saṅgāmeyyāma ati  tatiyam pi kho bhikkhave asurāḥ devehi saṅgāmesu
translated: Let’s fight the gods a third time.’🔽And a third time the asuras fought with the gods.

original: Tatiyampi kho, bhikkhave, devā jiniṁsu, asurā parājayiṁsu.
analyzed: tatiyam pi kho bhikkhave devāḥ jinisu asurāḥ parājayisu
translated: And a third time the gods won and the asuras lost.

original: Parājitā ca, bhikkhave, asurā bhītā asurapuraṁyeva pavisiṁsu.🔽Asurapuragatānañca pana, bhikkhave, asurānaṁ etadahosi:
analyzed: parājitāḥ ca bhikkhave asurāḥ bhītāḥ asura purayā iva pavisisu  asura pura gatānam ca pana bhikkhave asurānam etat ahosi
translated: And the defeated asuras fled in fear to the asura city.

original: ‘bhīruttānagatena kho dāni mayaṁ etarahi attanā viharāma akaraṇīyā devehī’ti.
analyzed: bhīru ttāna gatena kho dāni mayam etarahi attanā viharāma a karaṇīyāḥ devehi iti
translated: But when they had entered the city, they thought, ‘We now live in fear, defenseless against the gods.’

original: Devānampi, bhikkhave, etadahosi:
analyzed: devānam pi bhikkhave etat ahosi
translated: And the gods thought,

original: ‘bhīruttānagatena kho dāni asurā etarahi attanā viharanti akaraṇīyā amhehī’ti.
analyzed: bhīru ttāna gatena kho dāni asurāḥ etarahi attanā viharanti a karaṇīyāḥ amhehi iti
translated: ‘Now the asuras are living in a state of fear of me, powerless to retaliate.’

original: Evamevaṁ kho, bhikkhave, yasmiṁ samaye bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṁ savicāraṁ vivekajaṁ pītisukhaṁ paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati,
analyzed: evam evam kho bhikkhave yasmin samaye bhikkhu vivicca iva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi sa vitakkam sa vicāram viveka jam pīti sukham paṭhamam jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: In the same way, when a bhikkhu enters and dwells in the first jhana, which is accompanied by applied and sustained thought, with rapture and pleasure born of seclusion,

original: tasmiṁ, bhikkhave, samaye bhikkhussa evaṁ hoti:
analyzed: tasmi bhikkhave samaye bhikkhussa evam hoti
translated: on that occasion the bhikkhu thinks thus:

original: ‘bhīruttānagatena kho dānāhaṁ etarahi attanā viharāmi akaraṇīyo mārassā’ti.
analyzed: bhīru ttāna gatena kho dāna aham etarahi attanā viharāmi a karaṇīyaḥ mārassa ati
translated: ‘Now I am living in a state of fearlessness, powerless to retaliate.’

original: Mārassāpi, bhikkhave, pāpimato evaṁ hoti:
analyzed: mārassa api bhikkhave pāpimataḥ evam hoti
translated: And Mara thinks:

original: ‘bhīruttānagatena kho dāni bhikkhu etarahi attanā viharati akaraṇīyo mayhan’ti.
analyzed: bhīru ttāna gatena kho dāni bhikkhu etarahi attanā viharati a karaṇīyaḥ mayhanti
translated: ‘Now the bhikkhu is living in a state of fearlessness, powerless to retaliate.’

original: Yasmiṁ, bhikkhave, samaye bhikkhu vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā …pe… dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ …
analyzed: yasmin bhikkhave samaye bhikkhu vitakka vicārānam vūpasamā pe dutiyam jhānam
translated: “When a bhikkhu enters and dwells in the second jhana…

original: tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ …
analyzed: tatiyam jhānam
translated: in the third jhana…

original: catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati,
analyzed: catuttham jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: in the fourth jhana,

original: tasmiṁ, bhikkhave, samaye bhikkhussa evaṁ hoti:
analyzed: tasmi bhikkhave samaye bhikkhussa evam hoti
translated: on that occasion the bhikkhu thinks thus:

original: ‘bhīruttānagatena kho dānāhaṁ etarahi attanā viharāmi akaraṇīyo mārassā’ti.
analyzed: bhīru ttāna gatena kho dāna aham etarahi attanā viharāmi a karaṇīyaḥ mārassa ati
translated: ‘Now I live with fear left behind, and Māra has no hold on me.’

original: Mārassāpi, bhikkhave, pāpimato evaṁ hoti:
analyzed: mārassa api bhikkhave pāpimataḥ evam hoti
translated: And Māra thinks:

original: ‘bhīruttānagatena kho dāni bhikkhu etarahi attanā viharati, akaraṇīyo mayhan’ti.
analyzed: bhīru ttāna gatena kho dāni bhikkhu etarahi attanā viharati a karaṇīyaḥ mayhanti
translated: ‘Now the monk lives with fear left behind, and I have no hold on him.’

original: Yasmiṁ, bhikkhave, samaye bhikkhu sabbaso rūpasaññānaṁ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṁ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṁ amanasikārā ‘ananto ākāso’ti ākāsānañcāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: yasmi bhikkhave samaye bhikkhu sabbaso rūpa saññānam samatikkamā paṭigha saññānam atthaṅgamā nānatta saññānam amanasikārā anantaḥ ākāsaḥ ti ākāsānañcāyatanam upasampajja viharati
translated: When a monk, with the complete surmounting of perceptions of form, with the disappearance of perceptions of sensory impact, with non-attention to perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite,’ enters & remains in the dimension of the infinitude of space:

original: Ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, ‘bhikkhu antamakāsi māraṁ, apadaṁ vadhitvā māracakkhuṁ adassanaṁ gato pāpimato tiṇṇo loke visattikan’ti.
analyzed: ayam vuccati bhikkhave bhikkhu antam akāsi māra a padam vadhitvā māra cakkhum adassanam gataḥ pāpimataḥ tiṇṇaḥ loke visattikam ti
translated: This is called a monk who has made an end of the entailments, who has cut off the round, who has shattered the wheel, who has done away with the bridge, who has unmoored the boat, who has cut the fetters, who has made the river’s embankments collapse, who has uprooted the creeper, who has gone to the unploughed, untilled, undisturbed land, who has gone to the world’s end, who has gone to the far shore, who has gone to the most excellent freedom from entanglements.

original: Yasmiṁ, bhikkhave, samaye bhikkhu sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṁ samatikkamma ‘anantaṁ viññāṇan’ti viññāṇañcāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati …
analyzed: yasmi bhikkhave samaye bhikkhu sabbaso ākāsānañca āyatanam samatikkamma anantam viññāṇanti viññāṇañcāyatanam upasampajja viharati
translated: When a monk, with the complete surmounting of the dimension of the infinitude of space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite,’ enters & remains in the dimension of the infinitude of consciousness: …

original: sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṁ samatikkamma ‘natthi kiñcī’ti ākiñcaññāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati …
analyzed: sabbasas viññāṇañca āyatanam samatikkamma na atthi kiñci iti ākiñcaññāyatanam upasampajja viharati
translated: They completely surmount the dimension of the infinitude of consciousness, thinking ‘There is nothing at all.’ They enter & remain in the dimension of nothingness. …

original: sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanaṁ samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati …
analyzed: sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanam samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanam upasampajja viharati
translated: They completely surmount the dimension of nothingness, thinking ‘There is nothing at all.’ They enter & remain in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception. …

original: sabbaso nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṁ samatikkamma saññāvedayitanirodhaṁ upasampajja viharati, paññāya cassa disvā āsavā parikkhīṇā honti.
analyzed: sabbasas nevasaññā nāsañña āyatanam samatikkamma saññā vedayita nirodham upasampajja viharati paññāya ca ssa disvā āsavā parikkhīṇāḥ honti
translated: They completely surmount the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception. They enter & remain in the cessation of perception & feeling. And, having seen with discernment, their effluents are ended.

original: Ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, ‘bhikkhu antamakāsi māraṁ, apadaṁ vadhitvā māracakkhuṁ adassanaṁ gato pāpimato tiṇṇo loke visattikan’”ti.🔽Aṭṭhamaṁ.
analyzed: ayam vuccati bhikkhave bhikkhu antam akāsi māra a padam vadhitvā māra cakkhum adassanam gataḥ pāpimataḥ tiṇṇaḥ loke visattikam ti  aṭṭhama
translated: This is called a monk who has made an end to the underlying tendency to conceit, has cut off craving, has loosened the bonds, and—with the complete ending of the effluents—has directly experienced the effluent-free release of mind, release through discernment. He has gone beyond the measure of the world, and yet he is not without a measure.”🔽The eighth section on the one who has gone beyond the measure of the world is finished.

original: Aṅguttara Nikāya 9.40
analyzed: aṅguttara nikāya
translated: The Book of the Tens

original: 4. Mahāvagga
analyzed: mahāvagga
translated: The Greater Section

original: Nāgasutta
analyzed: nāgasutta
translated: The Elephant

original: “Yasmiṁ, bhikkhave, samaye āraññikassa nāgassa gocarapasutassa hatthīpi hatthiniyopi
analyzed: yasmi bhikkhave samaye āraññikassa nāgassa gocara pasutassa hatthī pi hatthi niyo pi
translated: “Monks, there are these eight amazing & astounding qualities of the elephant-treasure.

original: hatthikalabhāpi hatthicchāpāpi purato purato gantvā tiṇaggāni chindanti, tena, bhikkhave,
analyzed: hatthi kalabhā api hatthi chāpā api puratas puratas gantvā tiṇaggāni chindanti tena bhikkhave
translated: Which eight?

original: āraññiko nāgo aṭṭīyati harāyati jigucchati.🔽Yasmiṁ, bhikkhave, samaye āraññikassa nāgassa gocarapasutassa hatthīpi hatthiniyopi
analyzed: āraññikaḥ nāgaḥ aṭṭīyati harāyati jigucchati  yasmi bhikkhave samaye āraññikassa nāgassa gocara pasutassa hatthī pi hatthi niyo pi
translated: The wild bull elephant is disgusted, humiliated, & ashamed.

original: hatthikalabhāpi hatthicchāpāpi obhaggobhaggaṁ sākhābhaṅgaṁ khādanti, tena, bhikkhave,
analyzed: hatthi kalabhā api hatthi chāpā api obhagga ubhaggam sākhābhaṅgam khādanti tena bhikkhave
translated: “On the occasion when the wild bull elephant is going to the place for his food, the other elephants—the male elephants, female elephants, baby elephants, & elephant cubs—

original: āraññiko nāgo aṭṭīyati harāyati jigucchati.🔽Yasmiṁ, bhikkhave, samaye āraññikassa nāgassa ogāhaṁ otiṇṇassa hatthīpi hatthiniyopi
analyzed: āraññikaḥ nāgaḥ aṭṭīyati harāyati jigucchati  yasmi bhikkhave samaye āraññikassa nāgassa ogāham otiṇṇassa hatthī pi hatthiniyaḥ pi
translated: eat the broken-off pieces of his food. The wild bull elephant is disgusted, humiliated, & ashamed.

original: hatthikalabhāpi hatthicchāpāpi purato purato gantvā soṇḍāya udakaṁ āloḷenti, tena,
analyzed: hatthi kalabhā api hatthi chāpā api puratas puratas gantvā soṇḍāya udakam āloḍenti tena
translated: “On the occasion when the wild bull elephant is going to the place for his bathing & drinking, the other elephants—the male elephants, female elephants, baby elephants, & elephant cubs—

original: bhikkhave, āraññiko nāgo aṭṭīyati harāyati jigucchati.
analyzed: bhikkhave āraññikaḥ nāgaḥ aṭṭīyati harāyati jigucchati
translated: go in front of him, stirring up the water with their trunks. The wild bull elephant is disgusted, humiliated, & ashamed.

original: Yasmiṁ, bhikkhave, samaye āraññikassa nāgassa ogāhā uttiṇṇassa hatthiniyo kāyaṁ upanighaṁsantiyo gacchanti, tena, bhikkhave, āraññiko nāgo aṭṭīyati harāyati jigucchati.
analyzed: yasmi bhikkhave samaye āraññikassa nāgassa ogāhāḥ uttiṇṇassa hatthiniyaḥ kāyam upanighasantiyaḥ gacchanti tena bhikkhave āraññikaḥ nāgaḥ aṭṭīyati harāyati jigucchati
translated: “On the occasion when the wild bull elephant is coming out of the place for his bathing & drinking, the female elephants go along rubbing against his body. The wild bull elephant is disgusted, humiliated, & ashamed.

original: Tasmiṁ, bhikkhave, samaye āraññikassa nāgassa evaṁ hoti:
analyzed: tasmi bhikkhave samaye āraññikassa nāgassa evam hoti
translated: Then the forest-dwelling elephant thinks:

original: ‘ahaṁ kho etarahi ākiṇṇo viharāmi hatthīhi hatthinīhi hatthikalabhehi hatthicchāpehi.
analyzed: aham kho etarahi ākiṇṇaḥ viharāmi hatthīhi hatthinīhi hatthi kalabhehi hatthi chāpehi
translated: ‘At present I’m living hemmed in by elephants, bulls, cows, young elephants, & elephant cubs.

original: Chinnaggāni ceva tiṇāni khādāmi, obhaggobhaggañca me sākhābhaṅgaṁ khādanti, āvilāni ca pānīyāni pivāmi, ogāhā ca me uttiṇṇassa hatthiniyo kāyaṁ upanighaṁsantiyo gacchanti.
analyzed: chinnaggāni ca iva tiṇāni khādāmi obhagga ubhaggam ca me sākhābhaṅgam khādanti āvilāni ca pānīyāni pivāmi ogāhā ca me uttiṇṇassa hatthiniyaḥ kāyam upanighasantiyaḥ gacchanti
translated: I eat grass that’s been chewed up, and they eat the chewed-up bits of grass I drop. I drink disturbed water, and after I’ve come up from my bathing-place, cows rub against my body.

original: Yannūnāhaṁ eko gaṇasmā vūpakaṭṭho vihareyyan’ti.
analyzed: yat nūna aham ekaḥ gaṇasmai vūpakaṭṭhaḥ vihareyyanti
translated: Why don’t I live alone, withdrawn from the group?’

original: So aparena samayena eko gaṇasmā vūpakaṭṭho viharati, acchinnaggāni ceva tiṇāni khādati,🔽obhaggobhaggañcassa sākhābhaṅgaṁ na khādanti, anāvilāni ca pānīyāni pivati, ogāhā
analyzed: saḥ aparena samayena ekaḥ gaṇasmā vūpakaṭṭhaḥ viharati acchinna ggāni ca iva tiṇāni khādati  sākhābhaṅgam na khādanti anāvilāni ca pānīyāni pivati ogāhā
translated: “So after some time he lives alone, withdrawn from the group. He eats grass that hasn’t been chewed up,

original: cassa uttiṇṇassa na hatthiniyo kāyaṁ upanighaṁsantiyo gacchanti.
analyzed: cassa uttiṇṇassa na hatthiniyaḥ kāyam upanighasantiyaḥ gacchanti
translated: and the chewed-up bits of grass he drops aren’t eaten. He drinks undisturbed water, and after he’s come up from his bathing-place, cows don’t rub against his body.

original: Tasmiṁ, bhikkhave, samaye āraññikassa nāgassa evaṁ hoti:
analyzed: tasmi bhikkhave samaye āraññikassa nāgassa evam hoti
translated: Then the forest-dwelling elephant thinks:

original: ‘ahaṁ kho pubbe ākiṇṇo vihāsiṁ hatthīhi hatthinīhi hatthikalabhehi hatthicchāpehi,🔽chinnaggāni ceva tiṇāni khādiṁ, obhaggobhaggañca me sākhābhaṅgaṁ khādiṁsu, āvilāni
analyzed: aham kho pubbe ākiṇṇaḥ vihāsim hatthīhi hatthinīhi hatthi kalabhehi hatthi chāpehi  chinnaggāni ca iva tiṇāni khādi me sākhābhaṅgam khādisu āvilāni
translated: ‘Formerly, when I lived crowded with elephants,🔽I ate grass that had been cut by others, and others ate the broken branches I had pulled down. I drank disturbed water, and after I had come up from my bathing place,

original: ca pānīyāni apāyiṁ, ogāhā ca me uttiṇṇassa hatthiniyo kāyaṁ upanighaṁsantiyo agamaṁsu.
analyzed: ca pānīyāni apāyi ogāhā ca me uttiṇṇassa hatthiniyaḥ kāyam upanighasantiyaḥ agamasu
translated: elephants came and struck me with their tusks and feet.

original: Sohaṁ etarahi eko gaṇasmā vūpakaṭṭho viharāmi, acchinnaggāni ceva tiṇāni khādāmi,🔽obhaggobhaggañca me sākhābhaṅgaṁ na khādanti, anāvilāni ca pānīyāni pivāmi, ogāhā
analyzed: saḥ aham etarahi ekaḥ vūpakaṭṭhaḥ viharāmi acchinna ggāni ca iva tiṇāni khādāmi  me sākhābhaṅgam na khādanti anāvilāni ca pānīyāni pivāmi ogāhā
translated: But now I live alone, withdrawn in a secluded dwelling. I eat uncut grass,🔽and no one eats the broken branches I pull down. I drink undisturbed water, and after I have come up from my bathing place,

original: ca me uttiṇṇassa na hatthiniyo kāyaṁ upanighaṁsantiyo gacchantī’ti. So soṇḍāya sākhābhaṅgaṁ
analyzed: ca me uttiṇṇassa na hatthiniyaḥ kāyam upanighasantiyaḥ gacchanti iti saḥ soṇḍāya
translated: no elephants come and strike me with their tusks and feet.’ He breaks off a branch with his trunk,

original: bhañjitvā sākhābhaṅgena kāyaṁ parimajjitvā attamano soṇḍaṁ saṁharati.
analyzed: bhañjitvā sa akhā bhaṅgena kāyam parimajjitvā atta manaḥ soṇḍam saharati
translated: and after he has groomed himself with the branch, he retracts his trunk, pleased.

original: Evamevaṁ kho, bhikkhave, yasmiṁ samaye bhikkhu ākiṇṇo viharati bhikkhūhi bhikkhunīhi
analyzed: evam evam kho bhikkhave yasmin samaye bhikkhu ākiṇṇaḥ viharati bhikkhūhi bhikkhunīhi
translated: So too, monks, when a monk lives crowded with monks,

original: upāsakehi upāsikāhi raññā rājamahāmattehi titthiyehi titthiyasāvakehi, tasmiṁ, bhikkhave,
analyzed: upāsakehi upāsikāhi raññā rāja mahāmattehi titthiyehi titthiya sāvakehi tasmi bhikkhave
translated: with lay followers, lay followers’ sons, kings, royal ministers, and leaders of other religions and their disciples.

original: samaye bhikkhussa evaṁ hoti:
analyzed: samaye bhikkhussa evam hoti
translated: At that time he thinks,

original: ‘ahaṁ kho etarahi ākiṇṇo viharāmi bhikkhūhi bhikkhunīhi upāsakehi upāsikāhi raññā rājamahāmattehi titthiyehi titthiyasāvakehi.
analyzed: aham kho etarahi ākiṇṇaḥ viharāmi bhikkhūhi bhikkhunīhi upāsakehi upāsikāhi raññā rāja mahāmattehi titthiyehi titthiya sāvakehi
translated: ‘I’m staying too close to the monks, nuns, lay followers, kings, royal ministers, and leaders of other religions and their disciples.

original: Yannūnāhaṁ eko gaṇasmā vūpakaṭṭho vihareyyan’ti.🔽So vivittaṁ senāsanaṁ bhajati araññaṁ rukkhamūlaṁ pabbataṁ kandaraṁ giriguhaṁ susānaṁ vanapatthaṁ abbhokāsaṁ palālapuñjaṁ.
analyzed: yat nūna aham ekaḥ gaṇasmai vūpakaṭṭhaḥ vihareyyanti  so vivittam senāsanam bhajati araññam rukkha mūlam pabbatam kandaram giri guham su sānam vana pattham abbhokāsam palāla puñja
translated: Let me live alone, withdrawn from the group.’🔽He frequents remote lodgings, a forest, the foot of a tree, a mountain, a ravine, a hillside cave, a charnel ground, a jungle hut, or an open space.

original: So araññagato vā rukkhamūlagato vā suññāgāragato vā nisīdati pallaṅkaṁ ābhujitvā ujuṁ kāyaṁ paṇidhāya parimukhaṁ satiṁ upaṭṭhapetvā.
analyzed: saḥ arañña gataḥ vā rukkha mūla gataḥ vā suññāgāra gataḥ vā nisīdati pallaṅkam ābhujitvā ujum kāyam paṇidhāya parimukham satim upaṭṭhapetvā
translated: When he has gone to the wilderness, to the base of a tree, or to an empty building, he sits down, folding his legs crosswise, straightening his body, and establishing mindfulness in front of him.🔽He gives up desire for the world and lives with a mind without desire.

original: So abhijjhaṁ loke pahāya vigatābhijjhena cetasā viharati, abhijjhāya cittaṁ parisodheti;
analyzed: saḥ abhijjham loke pahāya vigata abhijjhena cetasā viharati abhijjhāya cittam parisodheti
translated: He purifies his mind of desire.

original: byāpādapadosaṁ pahāya abyāpannacitto viharati sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī, byāpādapadosā cittaṁ parisodheti;
analyzed: byāpāda padosam pahāya a byāpanna cittaḥ viharati sabba pāṇa bhūta hita anukampī byāpāda padosā cittam parisodheti
translated: He gives up ill will and resentment, and so with a mind freed from ill will, he dwells compassionate toward all living beings, and his mind is purified of ill will.

original: thinamiddhaṁ pahāya vigatathinamiddho viharati ālokasaññī sato sampajāno, thinamiddhā cittaṁ parisodheti;🔽uddhaccakukkuccaṁ pahāya anuddhato viharati ajjhattaṁ vūpasantacitto, uddhaccakukkuccā cittaṁ parisodheti;
analyzed: thinamiddham pahāya vigata thinamiddhaḥ viharati āloka saññī sataḥ sampajānaḥ thinamiddhā cittam parisodheti  uddhacca kukkuccam pahāya anuddhataḥ viharati ajjhattam vūpasanta cittaḥ uddhacca kukkuccā cittam parisodheti
translated: He gives up restlessness and remorse, and so without anxiety his mind becomes inwardly peaceful. He purifies his mind of restlessness and remorse.

original: vicikicchaṁ pahāya tiṇṇavicikiccho viharati akathaṅkathī kusalesu dhammesu, vicikicchāya cittaṁ parisodheti.
analyzed: vicikiccham pahāya tiṇṇa vicikicchaḥ viharati a kathaṅkathī kusalesu dhammesu vicikicchāya cittam parisodheti
translated: He gives up doubt, and so, being free of doubt about wholesome qualities, he purifies his mind of doubt.

original: So ime pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetaso upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe
analyzed: saḥ ime pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetasaḥ upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe
translated: He gives up these five hindrances, corruptions of the mind and weakeners of wisdom,

original: vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṁ savicāraṁ vivekajaṁ pītisukhaṁ paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: vivicca iva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi sa vitakkam sa vicāram viveka jam pīti sukham paṭhamam jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: and so, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unwholesome states, he enters and remains in the first jhāna, which consists of rapture and pleasure born of seclusion, and accompanied by thought and examination.

original: So attamano soṇḍaṁ saṁharati.
analyzed: saḥ atta manaḥ sa uṇḍam saharati
translated: He is pleased with that attainment, and he extols it.

original: Vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā …pe… dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ …
analyzed: vitakka vicārānam vūpasamā pe dutiyam jhānam
translated: With the subsiding of thought and examination, he enters and remains in the second jhāna, which consists of rapture and pleasure born of concentration, and is without thought and examination, …

original: tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ …🔽catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: tatiyam jhānam  catuttham jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: the fourth jhāna …

original: So attamano soṇḍaṁ saṁharati.
analyzed: saḥ atta manaḥ sa uṇḍam saharati
translated: and he withdraws his tusk satisfied.

original: Sabbaso rūpasaññānaṁ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṁ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṁ amanasikārā ‘ananto ākāso’ti ākāsānañcāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: sabbaso rūpa saññānam samatikkamā paṭigha saññānam atthaṅgamā nānatta saññānam amanasikārā anantaḥ ākāsaḥ ti ākāsānañcāyatanam upasampajja viharati
translated: Going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, he enters and remains in the dimension of the infinitude of consciousness.

original: So attamano soṇḍaṁ saṁharati.🔽Sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṁ samatikkamma ‘anantaṁ viññāṇan’ti viññāṇañcāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati …🔽sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṁ samatikkamma ‘natthi kiñcī’ti ākiñcaññāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati …
analyzed: saḥ atta manaḥ sa uṇḍam saharati  sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanam samatikkamma anantam viññāṇanti viññāṇañcāyatanam upasampajja viharati  sabbasas viññāṇañca āyatanam samatikkamma na atthi kiñci iti ākiñcaññāyatanam upasampajja viharati
translated: and he withdraws his tusk satisfied.🔽Going totally beyond the dimension of the infinitude of consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, he enters and remains in the dimension of nothingness. …

original: sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanaṁ samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati …
analyzed: sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanam samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanam upasampajja viharati
translated: Going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, he enters and remains in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception. …

original: sabbaso nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṁ samatikkamma saññāvedayitanirodhaṁ upasampajja viharati, paññāya cassa disvā āsavā parikkhīṇā honti.
analyzed: sabbasas nevasaññā nāsañña āyatanam samatikkamma saññā vedayita nirodham upasampajja viharati paññāya ca ssa disvā āsavā parikkhīṇāḥ honti
translated: Going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, he enters and remains in the cessation of perception and feeling. And, having seen with wisdom, his defilements come to an end.

original: So attamano soṇḍaṁ saṁharatī”ti.🔽Navamaṁ.
analyzed: saḥ atta manaḥ sa uṇḍam saharati iti  navama
translated: He withdraws his trunk satisfied.”🔽The ninth

original: Aṅguttara Nikāya 9.41
analyzed: aṅguttara nikāya
translated: The Book of the Fives

original: 4. Mahāvagga
analyzed: mahāvagga
translated: The Greater Division

original: Tapussasutta🔽Ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā mallesu viharati uruvelakappaṁ nāma mallānaṁ nigamo.
analyzed: tapussa sutta  ekam samayam bhagavā mallesu viharati uruvelakappam nāma mallānam nigamaḥ
translated: With Tapussa🔽One time the Lord was staying among the Mallas at Uruvelakappa.

original: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṁ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya uruvelakappaṁ piṇḍāya pāvisi.🔽Uruvelakappe piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṁ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto āyasmantaṁ ānandaṁ āmantesi:
analyzed: atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇha samayam nivāsetvā patta cīvaram ādāya uruvelakappam piṇḍāya pāvisi  uruvela kappe piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattam piṇḍapāta paṭikkantaḥ āyasmantam ānandam āmantesi
translated: Then, rising from his seclusion at the end of the day, the Lord went to the Mallas’ public hall and sat down on a seat made ready.🔽Then the Lord said to the Venerable Ananda:

original: “idheva tāva tvaṁ, ānanda, hohi, yāvāhaṁ mahāvanaṁ ajjhogāhāmi divāvihārāyā”ti.
analyzed: idhā iva tāva tvai ānanda hohi yāvā aham mahā vanam ajjhogāhāmi divāvihārāya ati
translated: “Ananda, you may go to the Mango Grove and inform the monks, saying: ‘The Teacher says that the monks should assemble in the hall of the central door, as he wishes to speak to them.’”

original: “Evaṁ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā ānando bhagavato paccassosi.
analyzed: eva bhante iti kho āyasmai ānandaḥ bhagavataḥ paccassosi
translated: “Yes, Lord,” Ven. Ānanda responded to the Blessed One.

original: Atha kho bhagavā mahāvanaṁ ajjhogāhetvā aññatarasmiṁ rukkhamūle divāvihāraṁ nisīdi.
analyzed: atha kho bhagavā mahā vanam ajjhogāhetvā aññatarasmin rukkha mūle divāvihāram nisīdi
translated: Then the Blessed One, entering the Great Wood, sat down at the root of a bilva sapling for the day’s abiding.

original: Atha kho tapusso gahapati yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṁ
analyzed: atha kho tapussaḥ gahapati yena ayasmai ānandaḥ tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā
translated: Then the householder Tapussa went to Ven. Ānanda and, on arrival, having bowed down to him, stood to one side.🔽As he was standing there, he said to Ven. Ānanda,

original: ānandaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho tapusso gahapati āyasmantaṁ ānandaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: ānandam abhivādetvā ekamantam nisīdi ekamantam nisinnaḥ kho tapussaḥ gahapati āyasmantam ānandam etat avoca
translated: and said to him:

original: “Mayaṁ, bhante ānanda, gihī kāmabhogino kāmārāmā kāmaratā kāmasammuditā.🔽Tesaṁ no, bhante, amhākaṁ gihīnaṁ kāmabhogīnaṁ kāmārāmānaṁ kāmaratānaṁ kāmasammuditānaṁ papāto viya khāyati, yadidaṁ nekkhammaṁ.
analyzed: bhante ānanda gihī kāma bhoginī kāma ārāmā kāma ratā kāma sammuditā  tesam naḥ bhante amhākam gihīnam kāma bhogīnam kāma ārāmānam kāma ratānam kāma sammuditānam papātaḥ viya khāyati yat idam nekkhamma
translated: “Venerable sir, we householders delight in making love, we enjoy making love, we are devoted to making love.🔽Renunciation seems to us like a precipice.

original: Sutaṁ metaṁ, bhante, ‘imasmiṁ dhammavinaye daharānaṁ daharānaṁ bhikkhūnaṁ nekkhamme cittaṁ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati etaṁ santanti passato’.
analyzed: sutam mā ita bhante imasmin dhamma vinaye daharānam daharānam bhikkhūnam nekkhamme cittam pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati etam santanti passato
translated: But, venerable sir, I have heard that in this Dhamma and Discipline the minds of young bhikkhus enter into the plane of the imperturbable and arrive at distinction.

original: Tayidaṁ, bhante, imasmiṁ dhammavinaye bhikkhūnaṁ bahunā janena visabhāgo, yadidaṁ nekkhamman”ti.
analyzed: bhante imasmin dhamma vinaye bhikkhūnam bahunā janena visabhāgaḥ yat idam nekkhammanti
translated: This seems to me to be a very difficult thing in this Dhamma and Discipline, namely, renunciation.”

original: “Atthi kho etaṁ, gahapati, kathāpābhataṁ bhagavantaṁ dassanāya.
analyzed: atthi kho eta gahapati kathāpābhatam bhagavantam dassanāya
translated: “There is, householder, a reason for that statement.

original: Āyāma, gahapati, yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamissāma; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavato etamatthaṁ ārocessāma.
analyzed: āyāma gahapati yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkamissāma upasaṅkamitvā bhagavataḥ etam attham ārocessāma
translated: “Come, householder, let’s go to the Blessed One and report this matter to him.

original: Yathā no bhagavā byākarissati tathā naṁ dhāressāmā”ti.
analyzed: yathā naḥ bhagavā byākarissati tathā nam dhāressāma ati
translated: Then we will remember it according to the Blessed One’s answer.”

original: “Evaṁ, bhante”ti kho tapusso gahapati āyasmato ānandassa paccassosi.
analyzed: eva bhante iti kho tapussaḥ gahapati āyasmataḥ ānandassa paccassosi
translated: “Yes, lord,” Tapussa the householder replied.

original: Atha kho āyasmā ānando tapussena gahapatinā saddhiṁ yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā
analyzed: atha kho āyasmai ānandaḥ tapussena gahapatinā saddhim yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā
translated: Then Ven. Ānanda, together with Tapussa the householder, went to the Blessed One and, on arrival,

original: bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: bhagavantam abhivādetvā ekamantam nisīdi ekamantam nisinnaḥ khalu āyasmai ānandaḥ bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: having bowed down to him, sat to one side. As he was sitting there, he said to the Blessed One,

original: “Ayaṁ, bhante, tapusso gahapati evamāha:🔽‘mayaṁ, bhante ānanda, gihī kāmabhogino kāmārāmā kāmaratā kāmasammuditā, tesaṁ no,
analyzed: bhante tapussaḥ gahapati evam āha  bhante ānanda gihī kāma bhogino kāma ārāmā kāma ratā kāma sammuditā tesam no
translated: “Lord, Tapussa the householder says this:

original: bhante, amhākaṁ gihīnaṁ kāmabhogīnaṁ kāmārāmānaṁ kāmaratānaṁ kāmasammuditānaṁ papāto
analyzed: bhante amhākam gihīnam kāma bhogīnam kāma ārāmānam kāma ratānam kāma sammuditānam papātaḥ
translated: ‘Lord, we householders live enjoying sensual pleasures, delighting in sensual pleasures, relishing sensual pleasures, burning with passion for sensual pleasures, our consciousness captive to sensual pleasures.

original: viya khāyati, yadidaṁ nekkhammaṁ’.
analyzed: viya khāyati yat idam nekkhamma
translated: The renunciation of sensual pleasures seems like a precipice to us.’

original: Sutaṁ metaṁ, bhante, ‘imasmiṁ dhammavinaye daharānaṁ daharānaṁ bhikkhūnaṁ nekkhamme cittaṁ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati etaṁ santanti passato.
analyzed: sutam mā ita bhante imasmin dhamma vinaye daharānam daharānam bhikkhūnam nekkhamme cittam pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati etam santanti passato
translated: I have heard that in this Dhamma-&-Vinaya the minds of young monks enter into seclusion, become steady, settle down, become unified, and are released.

original: Tayidaṁ, bhante, imasmiṁ dhammavinaye bhikkhūnaṁ bahunā janena visabhāgo yadidaṁ nekkhamman’”ti.
analyzed: bhante imasmin dhamma vinaye bhikkhūnam bahunā janena visabhāgaḥ yat idam nekkhammanti
translated: This is a quality of this Dhamma-&-Vinaya that is not shared by others: namely, seclusion.”

original: “Evametaṁ, ānanda, evametaṁ, ānanda.
analyzed: evam ete ānanda evam ete ānanda
translated: “So it is, Ānanda. So it is, Ānanda.

original: Mayhampi kho, ānanda, pubbeva sambodhā anabhisambuddhassa bodhisattasseva sato etadahosi:
analyzed: mayham pi kho ānanda pubbā iva sambodhā an abhisambuddhassa bodhisattassa iva sataḥ etat ahosi
translated: Before my self-awakening, while I was still just an unawakened Bodhisatta,

original: ‘sādhu nekkhammaṁ, sādhu paviveko’ti.
analyzed: sādhu nekkhamma sādhu paviveko ti
translated: I too thought, ‘It’s good to be secluded, it’s good to be secluded.’

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, nekkhamme cittaṁ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etaṁ santanti passato.
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda nekkhamme cittam na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etam santanti passato
translated: But my mind didn’t enter into seclusion, become steady, settle down, become unified, and released.

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, etadahosi:
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda etat ahosi
translated: The thought occurred to me:

original: ‘ko nu kho hetu ko paccayo, yena me nekkhamme cittaṁ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etaṁ santanti passato’?
analyzed: kaḥ nu kho hetu kaḥ paccayaḥ yena me nekkhamme cittam na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etam santanti passato
translated: ‘What is the cause, what is the reason why my mind does not launch out upon renunciation, nor settle down, nor become serene, nor unified, nor concentrated, but instead is anxious, and does not see renunciation as peaceful?’

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, etadahosi:
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda etat ahosi
translated: Then it occurred to me:

original: ‘kāmesu kho me ādīnavo adiṭṭho, so ca me abahulīkato, nekkhamme ca ānisaṁso anadhigato, so ca me anāsevito.
analyzed: kāmesu kho me ādīnavaḥ a diṭṭhaḥ saḥ ca me a bahulīkato nekkhamme ca ānisasaḥ an adhigato saḥ ca me an āsevito
translated: ‘I have not seen the danger in sensual pleasures, and have not made much of that, and I have not attained the reward of renunciation, and have not pursued that.

original: Tasmā me nekkhamme cittaṁ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etaṁ santanti passato’.
analyzed: tasmā me nekkhamme cittam na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etam santanti passato
translated: That is why my mind does not launch out upon renunciation, nor settle down, nor become serene, nor unified, nor concentrated, but instead is anxious, and does not see renunciation as peaceful.’

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, etadahosi:
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda etat ahosi
translated: Then it occurred to me:

original: ‘sace kho ahaṁ kāmesu ādīnavaṁ disvā taṁ bahulaṁ kareyyaṁ, nekkhamme ānisaṁsaṁ adhigamma tamāseveyyaṁ,
analyzed: sace kho aham kāmesu ādīnavam disvā tam bahulam kareyya nekkhamme ānisasam adhigamma tam āseveyya
translated: ‘Suppose that I were to see the danger in sensual pleasures, and were to make much of that, and were to attain the reward of renunciation, and were to pursue that.

original: ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ vijjati yaṁ me nekkhamme cittaṁ pakkhandeyya pasīdeyya santiṭṭheyya vimucceyya etaṁ santanti passato’.
analyzed: ṭhānam kho pana etat vijjati yat me nekkhamme cittam pakkhandeyya pasīdeyya santiṭṭheyya vimucceyya etam santanti passato
translated: It is possible that my mind would launch out upon renunciation, and settle down, and become serene, and unified, and concentrated, and not be anxious, and would see renunciation as peaceful.’

original: So kho ahaṁ, ānanda, aparena samayena kāmesu ādīnavaṁ disvā taṁ bahulamakāsiṁ, nekkhamme ānisaṁsaṁ adhigamma tamāseviṁ.
analyzed: saḥ kho aha ānanda aparena samayena kāmesu ādīnavam disvā tam bahulam akāsi nekkhamme ānisasam adhigamma tam āsevi
translated: Then, Ānanda, after some time, having seen the danger in sensual pleasures, I made light of them, I spurned them, I rejected them, I was disgusted by them, I rejected them.

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, nekkhamme cittaṁ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati etaṁ santanti passato.🔽So kho ahaṁ, ānanda, vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṁ savicāraṁ vivekajaṁ pītisukhaṁ paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharāmi.
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda nekkhamme cittam pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati etam santanti passato  saḥ kho aha ānanda vivicca iva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi sa vitakkam sa vicāram viveka jam pīti sukham paṭhamam jhānam upasampajja viharāmi
translated: My mind inclined to renunciation, became placid, settled, and composed regarding the state of renunciation.🔽Then, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unwholesome states, I entered and remained in the first jhāna, which consists of rapture and pleasure born of seclusion, and accompanied by thought and examination.

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, iminā vihārena viharato kāmasahagatā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti. Svassa me hoti ābādho.🔽Seyyathāpi, ānanda, sukhino dukkhaṁ uppajjeyya yāvadeva ābādhāya;
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda iminā vihārena viharato kāma sahagatā saññā manasikārā samudācaranti svassa me hoti ābādhaḥ  sā iyyathā api ānanda sukhinaḥ dukkham uppajjeyya yāvat eva ābādhāya
translated: But while I remained thus, there still occurred to me feelings born of the prior clinging to sensual pleasures. This was an affliction for me.

original: evamevassa me kāmasahagatā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti. Svassa me hoti ābādho.
analyzed: evam evassa me kāma sahagatāḥ saññā manasikārāḥ samudācaranti svassa me hoti ābādhaḥ
translated: Just as if a lump of clay, while still in the lump, were to be broken up and split apart, and not a single lump were to be seen, so too, while I remained thus, there still occurred to me feelings born of the prior clinging to sensual pleasures. This was an affliction for me.

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, etadahosi:
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda etat ahosi
translated: The thought occurred to me:

original: ‘yannūnāhaṁ vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā …pe… dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja vihareyyan’ti.
analyzed: yat nūna aham vitakka vicārānam vūpasamā pe dutiyam jhānam upasampajja vihareyyanti
translated: ‘Suppose I, with the stilling of thinking and pondering, enter and dwell in the second jhāna …’

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, avitakke cittaṁ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etaṁ santanti passato.
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda avitakke cittam na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etam santanti passato
translated: But my mind did not enter into concentration through lack of thinking and pondering, nor did it become still and settle down inside, thinking: ‘This is peaceful, this is sublime.’

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, etadahosi:
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda etat ahosi
translated: I thought:

original: ‘ko nu kho hetu ko paccayo, yena me avitakke cittaṁ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etaṁ santanti passato’?
analyzed: kaḥ nu kho hetu kaḥ paccayaḥ yena me avitakke cittam na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etam santanti passato
translated: ‘What is the cause, what is the reason, why my mind does not enter into concentration through lack of thinking and pondering, and does not become still and settle down inside, thinking: “This is peaceful, this is sublime”?

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, etadahosi:
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda etat ahosi
translated: I thought:

original: ‘vitakkesu kho me ādīnavo adiṭṭho, so ca me abahulīkato, avitakke ca ānisaṁso anadhigato, so ca me anāsevito.
analyzed: vitakkesu kho me ādīnavaḥ adiṭṭhaḥ saḥ ca me a bahulīkataḥ a vitakke ca ānisasaḥ an adhigataḥ saḥ ca me an āsevito
translated: ‘I have not seen the danger in thinking and pondering, and I have not developed the benefit in lack of thinking and pondering.

original: Tasmā me avitakke cittaṁ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etaṁ santanti passato’.
analyzed: tasmā me a vitakke cittam na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etam santanti passato
translated: That is why my mind does not enter into concentration through lack of thinking and pondering, and does not become still and settle down inside, thinking: “This is peaceful, this is sublime”.’

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, etadahosi:
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda etat ahosi
translated: I thought:

original: ‘sace kho ahaṁ vitakkesu ādīnavaṁ disvā taṁ bahulaṁ kareyyaṁ, avitakke ānisaṁsaṁ🔽adhigamma tamāseveyyaṁ, ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ vijjati yaṁ me avitakke cittaṁ pakkhandeyya
analyzed: sace kho aham vitakkesu ādīnavam disvā tam bahulam kareyya a vitakke ānisasa  adhigamma tam āseveyya ṭhānam kho pana itam vijjati yat me a vitakke cittam pakkhandeyya
translated: and if I see the benefit in not thinking and I pursue that,

original: pasīdeyya santiṭṭheyya vimucceyya etaṁ santanti passato’.
analyzed: pasīdeyya santiṭṭheyya vimucceyya etam santanti passato
translated: it’s possible that my mind will be released from the defilements through not thinking.’
