original: So kho ahaṁ, ānanda, aparena samayena vitakkesu ādīnavaṁ disvā taṁ bahulamakāsiṁ, avitakke ānisaṁsaṁ adhigamma tamāseviṁ.🔽Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, avitakke cittaṁ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati etaṁ santanti passato.🔽So kho ahaṁ, ānanda, vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā …pe… dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharāmi.
analyzed: saḥ kho aha ānanda aparena samayena vitakkesu ādīnavam disvā tam bahulam akāsi a vitakke ānisasam adhigamma tam āsevi  tassa mayhaḥ ānanda avitakke cittam pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati etam santanti passato  saḥ kho aha ānanda vitakka vicārānam vūpasamā pe dutiyam jhānam upasampajja viharāmi
translated: And so, Ānanda, after some time I saw danger in thinking and I frequently did that. I saw the benefit in not thinking and I pursued that.🔽And my mind became settled in samādhi through not thinking.🔽And so, Ānanda, with the stilling of thinking and pondering, I entered and remained in the second jhāna, which has the rapture and bliss born of samādhi, and has a unified mind within that is free from thinking and pondering.

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, iminā vihārena viharato vitakkasahagatā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti. Svassa me hoti ābādho.
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda iminā vihārena viharataḥ vitakka sahagatā saññā manasikārā samudācaranti svassa me hoti ābādhaḥ
translated: While I remained in this dwelling, thinking-related perceptions kept on occurring to me, and that was a sickness for me.

original: Seyyathāpi, ānanda, sukhino dukkhaṁ uppajjeyya yāvadeva ābādhāya;
analyzed: sā iyyathā api ānanda sukhinaḥ dukkham uppajjeyya yāvat eva ābādhāya
translated: Just as if a happy person were to experience pain,

original: evamevassa me vitakkasahagatā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti. Svassa me hoti ābādho.
analyzed: evam evassa me vitakka sahagatāḥ saññā manasikārāḥ samudācaranti svassa me hoti ābādhaḥ
translated: so too, while I was attending to bliss devoid of joy, painful feelings arose in me.

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, etadahosi:
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda etat ahosi
translated: I thought:

original: ‘yannūnāhaṁ pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca vihareyyaṁ sato ca sampajāno sukhañca kāyena🔽paṭisaṁvedeyyaṁ yaṁ taṁ ariyā ācikkhanti—upekkhako satimā sukhavihārīti tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ
analyzed: yat nūna aham pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca vihareyyam satas ca sampajāno sukham ca kāyena  paṭisavedeyyam yam tam ariyāḥ ācikkhanti upekkhako satimā sukha vihārī iti tatiyam jhāna
translated: ‘What if I were to dwell equanimous, mindful, and clearly comprehending, experiencing happiness with the body;🔽just as some worthy persons report: “The equanimous one is mindful, and experiences happiness with the body” —

original: upasampajja vihareyyan’ti.
analyzed: upasampajja vihareyyanti
translated: could I dwell equanimous, mindful, and clearly comprehending, experiencing happiness with the body, having previously abandoned bliss?

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, nippītike cittaṁ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etaṁ santanti passato.
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda nippītike cittam na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etam santanti passato
translated: But my mind did not find happiness in the absence of bliss, did not leap up at it, did not settle down upon it, and did not become convinced of it.

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, etadahosi:
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda etat ahosi
translated: I thought:

original: ‘ko nu kho hetu ko paccayo, yena me nippītike cittaṁ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etaṁ santanti passato’?
analyzed: kaḥ nu kho hetu kaḥ paccayaḥ yena me nippītike cittam na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etam santanti passato
translated: ‘What is the cause, what is the reason, why my mind does not find happiness in the absence of bliss, does not leap up at it, does not settle down upon it, and does not become convinced of it?

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, etadahosi:
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda etat ahosi
translated: I thought:

original: ‘pītiyā kho me ādīnavo adiṭṭho, so ca me abahulīkato, nippītike ca ānisaṁso anadhigato, so ca me anāsevito.
analyzed: pītiyā kho me ādīnavaḥ adiṭṭho saḥ ca me a bahulīkato nippītike ca ānisasaḥ an adhigataḥ saḥ ca me an āsevito
translated: ‘I haven’t seen the drawbacks of rapture, so it hasn’t been given up. I haven’t realized the benefits of the absence of rapture, so I haven’t developed it.

original: Tasmā me nippītike cittaṁ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etaṁ santanti passato’.
analyzed: tasmā me nippītike cittam na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etam santanti passato
translated: That’s why my mind doesn’t launch out and settle calmly and evenly on the absence of rapture.’

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, etadahosi:
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda etat ahosi
translated: Then I considered this:🔽‘If I see the drawbacks of rapture and make much of that,

original: ‘sace kho ahaṁ pītiyā ādīnavaṁ disvā taṁ bahulaṁ kareyyaṁ, nippītike ānisaṁsaṁ adhigamma🔽tamāseveyyaṁ, ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ vijjati yaṁ me nippītike cittaṁ pakkhandeyya pasīdeyya
analyzed: sace kho aham pītiyāḥ ādīnavam disvā tam bahulam kareyya nippītike ānisasam adhigamma  tam āseveyya ṭhānam kho pana itam vijjati yat me nippītike cittam pakkhandeyya pasīdeyya
translated: and if I realize the benefits of the absence of rapture and make much of that,

original: santiṭṭheyya vimucceyya etaṁ santanti passato’.🔽So kho ahaṁ, ānanda, aparena samayena pītiyā ādīnavaṁ disvā taṁ bahulamakāsiṁ, nippītike ānisaṁsaṁ adhigamma tamāseviṁ.
analyzed: santiṭṭheyya vimucceyya etam santanti passato  saḥ kho aha ānanda aparena samayena pītiyāḥ ādīnavam disvā tam bahulam akāsi nippītike ānisasam adhigamma tam āsevi
translated: it’s possible that my mind will launch out and settle calmly and evenly on the absence of rapture.’🔽So, Ānanda, at a later time I saw the drawbacks of rapture and made much of that. I realized the benefits of the absence of rapture and made much of that.

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, nippītike cittaṁ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati etaṁ santanti passato.
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda nippītike cittam pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati etam santanti passato
translated: And my mind launched out and settled calmly and evenly on the absence of rapture.

original: So kho ahaṁ, ānanda, pītiyā ca virāgā …pe… tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharāmi.
analyzed: saḥ kho aha ānanda pītiyā ca virāgā pe tatiyam jhānam upasampajja viharāmi
translated: With the fading away of rapture, I entered and remained in the third jhāna, which has no rapture and is based on equanimity and mindfulness.

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, iminā vihārena viharato pītisahagatā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti. Svassa me hoti ābādho.
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda iminā vihārena viharataḥ pīti sahagatā saññā manasikārā samudācaranti svassa me hoti ābādhaḥ
translated: While I was dwelling in this way, perception and attention accompanied by rapture assailed me. That was an affliction for me.

original: Seyyathāpi, ānanda, sukhino dukkhaṁ uppajjeyya yāvadeva ābādhāya;
analyzed: sā iyyathā api ānanda sukhinaḥ dukkham uppajjeyya yāvat eva ābādhāya
translated: Just as if a painful lump or boil had arisen in a certain place in the body, that would be an affliction for me.

original: evamevassa me pītisahagatā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti. Svassa me hoti ābādho.
analyzed: evam evassa me pīti sahagatāḥ saññā manasikārāḥ samudācaranti svassa me hoti ābādhaḥ
translated: So too, perception and attention accompanied by rapture assailed me. That was an affliction for me.

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, etadahosi:
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda etat ahosi
translated: I considered thus:

original: ‘yannūnāhaṁ sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja vihareyyan’ti.
analyzed: yat nūna aham sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbā iva somanassa domanassānam atthaṅgamā adukkham asukham upekkhā sati pārisuddhim catuttham jhānam upasampajja vihareyyanti
translated: ‘Suppose I dwell equanimous, mindful and clearly comprehending, having given up that perception of rapture.’

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, adukkhamasukhe cittaṁ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etaṁ santanti passato.
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda adukkham asukhe cittam na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etam santanti passato
translated: But my mind did not launch out upon equanimity, become placid, settle upon, and become composed regarding that perception of equanimity.

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, etadahosi:
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda etat ahosi
translated: I thought:

original: ‘ko nu kho hetu ko paccayo, yena me adukkhamasukhe cittaṁ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etaṁ santanti passato’?
analyzed: kaḥ nu kho hetu kaḥ paccayaḥ yena me adukkham asukhe cittam na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etam santanti passato
translated: ‘What is the cause, what is the reason, why my mind does not enter into concentration, does not settle down, does not become still and unified, when I think “This is peaceful, this is sublime,” in regard to neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling?

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, etadahosi:
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda etat ahosi
translated: I thought:

original: ‘upekkhāsukhe kho me ādīnavo adiṭṭho, so ca me abahulīkato, adukkhamasukhe ca ānisaṁso anadhigato, so ca me anāsevito.
analyzed: upekkhā sukhe kho me ādīnavaḥ a diṭṭhaḥ saḥ ca me a bahulīkato adukkhamasukhe ca ānisasaḥ an adhigataḥ saḥ ca me an āsevito
translated: ‘I have not seen the danger in neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling, I have not made much of it, I have not seen the benefit in the absence of neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling, I have not developed it.

original: Tasmā me adukkhamasukhe cittaṁ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etaṁ santanti passato’.
analyzed: tasmā me adukkham asukhe cittam na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etam santanti passato
translated: That is why my mind does not enter into concentration, does not settle down, does not become still and unified, when I think “This is peaceful, this is sublime,” in regard to the absence of neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling.’

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, etadahosi:
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda etat ahosi
translated: I thought:

original: ‘sace kho ahaṁ upekkhāsukhe ādīnavaṁ disvā taṁ bahulaṁ kareyyaṁ, adukkhamasukhe ānisaṁsaṁ
analyzed: sace kho aham upekkhā sukhe ādīnavam disvā tam bahulam kareyya adukkham asukhe ānisasa
translated: ‘If I see the danger in neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling, make much of it, and if I see the benefit in the absence of neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling, develop it,

original: adhigamma tamāseveyyaṁ, ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ vijjati yaṁ me adukkhamasukhe cittaṁ pakkhandeyya
analyzed: adhigamma tam āseveyya ṭhānam kho pana itam vijjati yat me adukkham asukhe cittam pakkhandeyya
translated: it is possible that my mind will enter into concentration, will settle down, will become still and unified, when I think “This is peaceful, this is sublime,” in regard to the absence of neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling.’

original: pasīdeyya santiṭṭheyya vimucceyya etaṁ santanti passato’.
analyzed: pasīdeyya santiṭṭheyya vimucceyya etam santanti passato
translated: I was gladdened, I was uplifted, I was inspired with confidence, I attained a state of peace.

original: So kho ahaṁ, ānanda, aparena samayena upekkhāsukhe ādīnavaṁ disvā taṁ bahulamakāsiṁ adukkhamasukhe ānisaṁsaṁ adhigamma tamāseviṁ.🔽Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, adukkhamasukhe cittaṁ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati etaṁ santanti passato.🔽So kho ahaṁ, ānanda, sukhassa ca pahānā …pe… catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharāmi.
analyzed: saḥ kho aha ānanda aparena samayena upekkhā sukhe ādīnavam disvā tam bahulam akāsim adukkham asukhe ānisasam adhigamma tam āsevi  tassa mayhaḥ ānanda adukkham asukhe cittam pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati etam santanti passato  so kho aha ānanda sukhassa ca pahānā pe catuttham jhānam upasampajja viharāmi
translated: “Then, Ānanda, after some time I saw danger in the pleasure of equanimity and I discerned the escape from it.🔽I discerned that equanimity as peaceful, that equanimity as sublime.🔽“Then, Ānanda, with the fading away as well of rapture, I entered and remained in the third jhāna, which has no pleasure, only equanimity, and mindfulness imbued with pleasure.

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, iminā vihārena viharato upekkhāsahagatā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti. Svassa me hoti ābādho.
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda iminā vihārena viharataḥ upekkhā sahagatā saññā manasikārā samudācaranti svassa me hoti ābādhaḥ
translated: While I remained thus, perceptions and attentions accompanied by pleasure assailed me. That was an affliction for me.

original: Seyyathāpi, ānanda, sukhino dukkhaṁ uppajjeyya yāvadeva ābādhāya;
analyzed: sā iyyathā api ānanda sukhinaḥ dukkham uppajjeyya yāvat eva ābādhāya
translated: Just as if a skilled butcher or his apprentice were to carve up an ox’s hide with a sharp razor,

original: evamevassa me upekkhāsahagatā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti. Svassa me hoti ābādho.
analyzed: evam evassa me upekkhā sahagatāḥ saññā manasikārāḥ samudācaranti svassa me hoti ābādhaḥ
translated: so too, while I remained thus, perceptions and attentions accompanied by pleasure assailed me. That was an affliction for me.

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, etadahosi:
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda etat ahosi
translated: “Then, Ānanda, I thought:

original: ‘yannūnāhaṁ sabbaso rūpasaññānaṁ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṁ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṁ amanasikārā “ananto ākāso”ti ākāsānañcāyatanaṁ upasampajja vihareyyan’ti.
analyzed: yat nūna aham sabbaso rūpa saññānam samatikkamā paṭigha saññānam atthaṅgamā nānatta saññānam amanasikārā anantaḥ ākāsaḥ iti ākāsānañcāyatanam upasampajja vihareyyanti
translated: ‘Suppose I were to completely surmount the perception of material forms, the perception of impingement, and the perception of diversity, and attend to the signless sphere of infinite space, thus: “Space is infinite.”’

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, ākāsānañcāyatane cittaṁ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etaṁ santanti passato.
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda ākāsa anañca āyatane cittam na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etam santanti passato
translated: But my mind did not enter into that signless concentration of mind and acquire confidence, steadiness, and decision.

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, etadahosi:
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda etat ahosi
translated: I considered thus:

original: ‘ko nu kho hetu ko paccayo, yena me ākāsānañcāyatane cittaṁ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etaṁ santanti passato’?
analyzed: kaḥ nu kho hetu kaḥ paccayaḥ yena me ākāsānañcāyatane cittam na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etam santanti passato
translated: ‘What is the cause, what is the reason, why my mind does not enter into that signless concentration of mind and acquire confidence, steadiness, and decision?

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, etadahosi:
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda etat ahosi
translated: I considered thus:

original: ‘rūpesu kho me ādīnavo adiṭṭho, so ca abahulīkato, ākāsānañcāyatane ca ānisaṁso anadhigato, so ca me anāsevito.
analyzed: rūpesu kho me ādīnavaḥ adiṭṭho saḥ ca a bahulīkato ākāsa anañcāyatane ca ānisasaḥ an adhigato saḥ ca me an āsevito
translated: ‘The danger in the perception of material forms has not been seen by me as it actually is present, the outcome of the perception of material forms has not been seen by me as it actually is present, the diversity of the perception of material forms has not been seen by me as it actually is present, the outcome of the diversity of the perception of material forms has not been seen by me as it actually is present.

original: Tasmā me ākāsānañcāyatane cittaṁ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etaṁ santanti passato’.
analyzed: tasmā me ākāsānañcāyatane cittam na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etam santanti passato
translated: So my mind did not enter into concentration, nor settle down, nor become still in the element of the infinitude of space, and I did not perceive it as peaceful.

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, etadahosi:
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda etat ahosi
translated: I considered:

original: ‘sace kho ahaṁ rūpesu ādīnavaṁ disvā taṁ bahulaṁ kareyyaṁ, ākāsānañcāyatane ānisaṁsaṁ🔽adhigamma tamāseveyyaṁ, ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ vijjati yaṁ me ākāsānañcāyatane cittaṁ
analyzed: sace kho aham rūpesu ādīnavam disvā tam bahulam kareyya ākāsānam ca āyatane ānisasa  adhigamma tam āseveyya ṭhānam kho pana itam vijjati yam me ākāsānaṃ ca āyatane
translated: ‘Suppose that I, having seen danger in forms, make much of that,

original: pakkhandeyya pasīdeyya santiṭṭheyya vimucceyya etaṁ santanti passato’.
analyzed: pakkhandeyya pasīdeyya santiṭṭheyya vimucceyya etam santanti passato
translated: and having gained the benefit in the element of the infinitude of space, attend to that. It is possible that my mind will enter into concentration, settle down, become still in the element of the infinitude of space, and I will perceive it as peaceful.’🔽Then, Ananda, after some time, having seen danger in forms, I made much of that,

original: So kho ahaṁ, ānanda, aparena samayena rūpesu ādīnavaṁ disvā taṁ bahulamakāsiṁ, ākāsānañcāyatane ānisaṁsaṁ adhigamma tamāseviṁ.
analyzed: saḥ khalu aha ānanda aparena samayena rūpesu ādīnavam disvā tam bahulam akāsi ākāsa anañca āyatane ānisasam adhigamma tam āsevi
translated: and having gained the benefit in the element of the infinitude of space, I attended to that.

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, ākāsānañcāyatane cittaṁ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati etaṁ santanti passato.
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda ākāsānañcāyatane cittam pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati etam santanti passato
translated: My mind entered into concentration, settled down, became still in the element of the infinitude of space, and I perceived it as peaceful.

original: So kho ahaṁ, ānanda, sabbaso rūpasaññānaṁ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṁ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṁ amanasikārā ‘ananto ākāso’ti ākāsānañcāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharāmi.
analyzed: saḥ kho aha ānanda sabbaso rūpa saññānam samatikkamā paṭigha saññānam atthaṅgamā nānatta saññānam amanasikārā anantaḥ ākāsaḥ iti ākāsa anañca āyatanam upasampajja viharāmi
translated: Having completely transcended the sphere of endless space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite,’ I entered and dwelt in the sphere of infinite consciousness.

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, iminā vihārena viharato rūpasahagatā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti. Svassa me hoti ābādho.🔽Seyyathāpi, ānanda, sukhino dukkhaṁ uppajjeyya yāvadeva ābādhāya;
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda iminā vihārena viharataḥ rūpa sahagatā saññā manasikārā samudācaranti svassa me hoti ābādhaḥ  sā iyyathā api ānanda sukhinaḥ dukkham uppajjeyya yāvat eva ābādhāya
translated: So, Ānanda, with the complete surmounting of perceptions of form, with the disappearance of perceptions of sensory impact, with non-attention to perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite,’ I entered and dwelt in the base of the infinity of space.

original: evamevassa me rūpasahagatā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti. Svassa me hoti ābādho.
analyzed: evam evassa me rūpa sahagatāḥ saññā manasikārāḥ samudācaranti svassa me hoti ābādhaḥ
translated: But while I dwelt there, perceptions and attentions accompanied by form occurred in my consciousness as afflictive.🔽Just as if a skilled butcher or his apprentice were to carve up an ox’s hide with a sharp razor and the water and mud inside and outside were to stick to the razor and adhere to it, so too, while I dwelt there, perceptions and attentions accompanied by form occurred in my consciousness as afflictive.

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, etadahosi:
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda etat ahosi
translated: The thought occurred to me:

original: ‘yannūnāhaṁ sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṁ samatikkamma “anantaṁ viññāṇan”ti viññāṇañcāyatanaṁ upasampajja vihareyyan’ti.
analyzed: yat nūna aham sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanam samatikkamma anantam viññāṇanti viññāṇañcāyatanam upasampajja vihareyyanti
translated: ‘What if I were to completely surmount the base of the infinity of space, to be aware that “consciousness is infinite,” and to enter and dwell in the base of the infinity of consciousness?’

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, viññāṇañcāyatane cittaṁ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etaṁ santanti passato.
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda viññāṇañcāyatane cittam na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etam santanti passato
translated: But my mind did not launch out upon the base of the infinity of consciousness, did not become placid, settled, and focused on that, nor was my mind released upon it.

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, etadahosi:
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda etat ahosi
translated: I considered:

original: ‘ko nu kho hetu ko paccayo, yena me viññāṇañcāyatane cittaṁ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etaṁ santanti passato’?
analyzed: kaḥ nu kho hetu kaḥ paccayaḥ yena me viññāṇañcāyatane cittam na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etam santanti passato
translated: ‘What is the cause, what is the reason, why my mind does not launch out upon the base of infinite consciousness, become placid, settled, and focused on it?

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, etadahosi:
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda etat ahosi
translated: I considered:

original: ‘ākāsānañcāyatane kho me ādīnavo adiṭṭho, so ca abahulīkato, viññāṇañcāyatane ca ānisaṁso anadhigato, so ca me anāsevito.
analyzed: ākāsānañca āyatane kho me ādīnavaḥ adiṭṭho saḥ ca a bahulīkato viññāṇañcāyatane ca ānisasaḥ an adhigato saḥ ca me an āsevito
translated: ‘I have not seen the danger in the base of infinite space, and I have not developed the base of infinite consciousness.

original: Tasmā me viññāṇañcāyatane cittaṁ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etaṁ santanti passato’.
analyzed: tasmā me viññāṇañcāyatane cittam na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etam santanti passato
translated: That is why my mind does not launch out upon the base of infinite consciousness, become placid, settled, and focused on it.’

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, etadahosi:
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda etat ahosi
translated: I considered:

original: ‘sace kho ahaṁ ākāsānañcāyatane ādīnavaṁ disvā taṁ bahulaṁ kareyyaṁ, viññāṇañcāyatane
analyzed: sace kho aham ākāsānañcāyatane ādīnavam disvā tam bahulam kareyya viññāṇañcāyatane
translated: ‘If, having seen the danger in the base of infinite space, I develop the base of infinite consciousness,

original: ānisaṁsaṁ adhigamma tamāseveyyaṁ, ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ vijjati yaṁ me viññāṇañcāyatane
analyzed: ānisasam adhigamma tam āseveyya ṭhānam kho pana itam vijjati yam me viññāṇam ca āyatane
translated: and having attained the base of infinite consciousness, I develop concentration with in-&-out breathing, it is possible that my mind will launch out upon the base of infinite consciousness, become placid, settled, and focused on it.

original: cittaṁ pakkhandeyya pasīdeyya santiṭṭheyya vimucceyya etaṁ santanti passato’.
analyzed: cittam pakkhandeyya pasīdeyya santiṭṭheyya vimucceyya etam santanti passato
translated: my mind would enter into that state of nothingness and find peace there.’🔽“Then, Ānanda, after some time, seeing the danger in the base of infinite space, I turned away from it.

original: So kho ahaṁ, ānanda, aparena samayena ākāsānañcāyatane ādīnavaṁ disvā taṁ bahulamakāsiṁ, viññāṇañcāyatane ānisaṁsaṁ adhigamma tamāseviṁ.🔽Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, viññāṇañcāyatane cittaṁ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati etaṁ santanti passato.
analyzed: saḥ kho aha ānanda aparena samayena ākāsa anañca āyatane ādīnavam disvā tam bahulam akāsi viññāṇañcāyatane ānisasam adhigamma tam āsevi  tassa mayhaḥ ānanda viññāṇañcāyatane cittam pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati etam santanti passato
translated: I had already seen the benefit in the base of infinite consciousness, so I entered and remained there.🔽My mind entered into that state of infinite consciousness and found peace there.

original: So kho ahaṁ, ānanda, sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṁ samatikkamma ‘anantaṁ viññāṇan’ti viññāṇañcāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharāmi.
analyzed: saḥ kho aha ānanda sabbaso ākāsānañca āyatanam samatikkamma anantam viññāṇanti viññāṇañcāyatanam upasampajja viharāmi
translated: “Then, Ānanda, with the complete transcendence of the base of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite,’ I entered and remained in the base of infinite consciousness.

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, iminā vihārena viharato ākāsānañcāyatanasahagatā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti. Svassa me hoti ābādho.
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda iminā vihārena viharataḥ ākāsa anañca āyatana sahagatā saññā manasikārā samudācaranti svassa me hoti ābādhaḥ
translated: While I remained in this dwelling, mind-objects connected with the base of infinite space occurred to me as objects of thought, and that was an affliction for me.

original: Seyyathāpi, ānanda, sukhino dukkhaṁ uppajjeyya yāvadeva ābādhāya;
analyzed: sā iyyathā api ānanda sukhinaḥ dukkham uppajjeyya yāvat eva ābādhāya
translated: Just as pain might arise for one who is happy,

original: evamevassa me ākāsānañcāyatanasahagatā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti. Svassa me hoti ābādho.
analyzed: evam evassa me ākāsa anañcāyatana sahagatā saññā manasikārā samudācaranti svassa me hoti ābādhaḥ
translated: In the same way, when I was paying attention to the perception belonging to the base of infinite space, I was sick.

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, etadahosi:🔽‘yannūnāhaṁ sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṁ samatikkamma “natthi kiñcī”ti ākiñcaññāyatanaṁ upasampajja vihareyyan’ti.
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda etat ahosi  yat nūna aham sabbasas viññāṇañca āyatanam samatikkamma na atthi kiñci iti ākiñcaññāyatanam upasampajja vihareyyanti
translated: I thought:🔽‘Why don’t I, by completely transcending the base of infinite consciousness, aware that “there is nothing at all”, enter and remain in the base of nothingness?’

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, ākiñcaññāyatane cittaṁ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etaṁ santanti passato.
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda ākiñcaññāyatane cittam na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etam santanti passato
translated: But my mind did not enter into that state and remain in that state.

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, etadahosi:
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda etat ahosi
translated: I thought:

original: ‘ko nu kho hetu ko paccayo, yena me ākiñcaññāyatane cittaṁ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etaṁ santanti passato’?
analyzed: kaḥ nu kho hetu kaḥ paccayaḥ yena me ākiñcaññāyatane cittam na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etam santanti passato
translated: ‘What is the cause, what is the reason why my mind does not enter into that state and remain in that state?’

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, etadahosi:
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda etat ahosi
translated: I thought:

original: ‘viññāṇañcāyatane kho me ādīnavo adiṭṭho, so ca me abahulīkato, ākiñcaññāyatane ca ānisaṁso anadhigato, so ca me anāsevito.
analyzed: viññāṇañcāyatane kho me ādīnavaḥ a diṭṭhaḥ saḥ ca me a bahulīkato ākiñcaññāyatane ca ānisasaḥ an adhigato saḥ ca me an āsevito
translated: ‘I have not seen the danger in the base of infinite consciousness, and I have not developed it. I have not realized the benefit in the base of nothingness, and I have not properly concentrated on it.

original: Tasmā me ākiñcaññāyatane cittaṁ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etaṁ santanti passato’.
analyzed: tasmā me ākiñcaññāyatane cittam na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etam santanti passato
translated: So my mind did not launch out upon it, nor become placid, settled, and resolute in it.

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, etadahosi:🔽‘sace kho ahaṁ viññāṇañcāyatane ādīnavaṁ disvā taṁ bahulaṁ kareyyaṁ, ākiñcaññāyatane🔽ānisaṁsaṁ adhigamma tamāseveyyaṁ, ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ vijjati yaṁ me ākiñcaññāyatane
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda etat ahosi  sace kho aham viññāṇañcāyatane ādīnavam disvā tam bahulam kareyya ākiñcaññāyatane  ānisasam adhigamma tam āseveyya ṭhānam kho pana itam vijjati yat me ākiñcaññāyatane
translated: I considered:

original: cittaṁ pakkhandeyya pasīdeyya santiṭṭheyya vimucceyya etaṁ santanti passato’.
analyzed: cittam pakkhandeyya pasīdeyya santiṭṭheyya vimucceyya etam santanti passato
translated: ‘If I see danger in the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception and frequently dwell on that danger, and if I see benefit in the base of nothingness and frequently dwell on that benefit, it is possible that my mind will launch out upon the base of nothingness, will become placid, settled, and resolute in it.

original: So kho ahaṁ, ānanda, aparena samayena viññāṇañcāyatane ādīnavaṁ disvā taṁ bahulamakāsiṁ, ākiñcaññāyatane ānisaṁsaṁ adhigamma tamāseviṁ.
analyzed: saḥ kho aha ānanda aparena samayena viññāṇañcāyatane ādīnavam disvā tam bahulam akāsi ākiñcaññāyatane ānisasam adhigamma tam āsevi
translated: So, Ānanda, after some time I saw danger in the base of infinite consciousness and frequently dwelled on that danger, and I saw benefit in the base of nothingness and frequently dwelled on that benefit.

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, ākiñcaññāyatane cittaṁ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati etaṁ santanti passato.
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda ākiñcaññāyatane cittam pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati etam santanti passato
translated: As I did so, my mind launched out upon the base of nothingness, became placid, settled, and resolute in it.

original: So kho ahaṁ, ānanda, sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṁ samatikkamma ‘natthi kiñcī’ti ākiñcaññāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharāmi.
analyzed: saḥ kho aha ānanda sabbaso viññāṇañca āyatanam samatikkamma na atthi kiñci iti ākiñcaññāyatanam upasampajja viharāmi
translated: I completely surmount the base of infinite consciousness. Aware that ‘there is nothing,’ I enter and remain in the base of nothingness.

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, iminā vihārena viharato viññāṇañcāyatanasahagatā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti. Svassa me hoti ābādho.
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda iminā vihārena viharataḥ viññāṇañca āyatana sahagatā saññā manasikārā samudācaranti svassa me hoti ābādhaḥ
translated: But while I was dwelling in this way, consciousness related to the base of infinite consciousness occasionally occurred in me. That was an affliction for me.

original: Seyyathāpi, ānanda, sukhino dukkhaṁ uppajjeyya yāvadeva ābādhāya;
analyzed: sā iyyathā api ānanda sukhinaḥ dukkham uppajjeyya yāvat eva ābādhāya
translated: Just as if a painful lump or boil had arisen in a certain place in the body,

original: evamevassa me viññāṇañcāyatanasahagatā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti. Svassa me hoti ābādho.
analyzed: evam evassa me viññāṇañcāyatana sahagatā saññā manasikārā samudācaranti svassa me hoti ābādhaḥ
translated: so consciousness related to the base of infinite consciousness occurred in me. That was an affliction for me.

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, etadahosi:
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda etat ahosi
translated: I thought:

original: ‘yannūnāhaṁ sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanaṁ samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṁ upasampajja vihareyyan’ti.
analyzed: yat nūna aham sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanam samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanam upasampajja vihareyyanti
translated: ‘What if I were to completely surmount the base of nothingness and enter and remain in the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception?’

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, nevasaññānāsaññāyatane cittaṁ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etaṁ santanti passato.
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda nevasaññānāsaññāyatane cittam na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etam santanti passato
translated: But my mind did not launch out upon that Dhamma, settle down upon it, and become resolute about it. I saw that as an affliction.

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, etadahosi:
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda etat ahosi
translated: I thought:

original: ‘ko nu kho hetu ko paccayo, yena me nevasaññānāsaññāyatane cittaṁ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etaṁ santanti passato’?
analyzed: kaḥ nu kho hetu kaḥ paccayaḥ yena me nevasaññānāsaññāyatane cittam na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etam santanti passato
translated: ‘What is the cause, what is the reason why my mind does not enter into concentration, does not become settled and decided, because of the perception of the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception?

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, etadahosi:
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda etat ahosi
translated: Then it occurred to me:

original: ‘ākiñcaññāyatane kho me ādīnavo adiṭṭho, so ca me abahulīkato, nevasaññānāsaññāyatane ca ānisaṁso anadhigato, so ca me anāsevito.
analyzed: ākiñcaññāyatane kho me ādīnavaḥ adiṭṭhaḥ saḥ ca me a bahulīkato nevasaññānāsaññāyatane ca ānisasaḥ anadhigato saḥ ca me anāsevito
translated: ‘The danger in the base of nothingness has not been seen by me, and that has not been developed, while the benefit in the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception has not been realised, and that has not been repeatedly practiced.

original: Tasmā me nevasaññānāsaññāyatane cittaṁ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etaṁ santanti passato’.
analyzed: tasmā me nevasaññānāsaññāyatane cittam na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etam santanti passato
translated: That is why my mind does not launch out upon the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception and become settled and firm in it, so that I see it as peaceful.’

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, etadahosi:🔽‘sace kho ahaṁ ākiñcaññāyatane ādīnavaṁ disvā taṁ bahulaṁ kareyyaṁ, nevasaññānāsaññāyatane
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda etat ahosi  sace kho aham ākiñcaññāyatane ādīnavam disvā tam bahulam kareyya nevasaññānāsaññāyatane
translated: Then it occurred to me:🔽‘Suppose that I, having seen the danger in the base of nothingness, develop that,

original: ānisaṁsaṁ adhigamma tamāseveyyaṁ, ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ vijjati yaṁ me nevasaññānāsaññāyatane
analyzed: ānisasam adhigamma tam āseveyya ṭhānam kho pana itam vijjati yat me na ivasaññā nāsañña āyatane
translated: and having realised the benefit in the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception, repeatedly practice that. It is possible that my mind will launch out upon the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception🔽and become settled and firm in it, so that I see it as peaceful.’

original: cittaṁ pakkhandeyya pasīdeyya santiṭṭheyya vimucceyya etaṁ santanti passato’.
analyzed: cittam pakkhandeyya pasīdeyya santiṭṭheyya vimucceyya etam santanti passato
translated: my mind would enter into that state and acquire confidence, steadiness, and decision.

original: So kho ahaṁ, ānanda, aparena samayena ākiñcaññāyatane ādīnavaṁ disvā taṁ bahulamakāsiṁ, nevasaññānāsaññāyatane ānisaṁsaṁ adhigamma tamāseviṁ.
analyzed: saḥ kho aha ānanda aparena samayena ākiñcaññāyatane ādīnavam disvā tam bahulam akāsi nevasaññā nāsaññāyatane ānisasam adhigamma tam āsevi
translated: “Then, Ānanda, after some time I saw danger in the base of nothingness and turned away from it; I directly knew it as it really is, ‘This is not mine, this I am not, this is not my self.’🔽Then my mind entered into the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception and acquired confidence, steadiness, and decision.🔽“Then, Ānanda, I directly knew: ‘There is an escape beyond the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.’

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, nevasaññānāsaññāyatane cittaṁ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati etaṁ santanti passato.🔽So kho ahaṁ, ānanda, sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanaṁ samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharāmi.
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda nevasaññānāsaññāyatane cittam pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati etam santanti passato  saḥ kho aha ānanda sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanam samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanam upasampajja viharāmi
translated: “Then, Ānanda, when I had understood that the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception is stilled but not the arising and passing away of consciousness, I directly knew: ‘There is an escape beyond the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.’

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, iminā vihārena viharato ākiñcaññāyatanasahagatā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti. Svassa me hoti ābādho.
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda iminā vihārena viharataḥ ākiñcaññāyatana sahagatā saññā manasikārā samudācaranti svassa me hoti ābādhaḥ
translated: “When, Ānanda, I was striving like this, endeavouring like this, with such a painful practice and such a painful endeavour, perception and attention accompanied by form arose in me. That was an affliction for me.

original: Seyyathāpi, ānanda, sukhino dukkhaṁ uppajjeyya yāvadeva ābādhāya;
analyzed: sā iyyathā api ānanda sukhinaḥ dukkham uppajjeyya yāvat eva ābādhāya
translated: Just as if a sharp-pointed sword were to be thrust into my head,

original: evamevassa me ākiñcaññāyatanasahagatā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti. Svassa me hoti ābādho.
analyzed: evam evassa me ākiñcaññāyatana sahagatā saññā manasikārā samudācaranti svassa me hoti ābādhaḥ
translated: In the same way, when I was practicing the practice that is painful now and results in pain in the future, painful now and blissful later, and painful now and resulting in bliss in the future, painful now and resulting in pain in the future, painful now and resulting in bliss in the future, and painful now and neither painful nor blissful in the future, I was sick.

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, etadahosi:🔽‘yannūnāhaṁ nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṁ samatikkamma saññāvedayitanirodhaṁ upasampajja vihareyyan’ti.
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda etat ahosi  yat nūna aham nevasaññānāsaññāyatanam samatikkamma saññā vedayita nirodham upasampajja vihareyyanti
translated: I thought:🔽‘What if I were to surmount the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception, enter and remain in the cessation of perception and feeling, and dwell having entered into that cessation?’

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, saññāvedayitanirodhe cittaṁ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etaṁ santanti passato.
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda saññā vedayita nirodhe cittam na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etam santanti passato
translated: But my mind did not launch out upon it, settle down upon it, and become resolute upon it. I did not see it as peaceful.

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, etadahosi:
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda etat ahosi
translated: I thought:

original: ‘ko nu kho hetu, ko paccayo, yena me saññāvedayitanirodhe cittaṁ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etaṁ santanti passato’?
analyzed: kaḥ nu kho hetu kaḥ paccayaḥ yena me saññā vedayita nirodhe cittam na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etam santanti passato
translated: ‘What is the cause, what is the reason, why my mind does not launch out upon that state, settle down upon it, and become resolute upon it? I do not see it as peaceful.

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, etadahosi:
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda etat ahosi
translated: I thought:

original: ‘nevasaññānāsaññāyatane kho me ādīnavo adiṭṭho, so ca me abahulīkato, saññāvedayitanirodhe ca ānisaṁso anadhigato, so ca me anāsevito.
analyzed: nevasaññānāsaññāyatane kho me ādīnavaḥ adiṭṭho saḥ ca me a bahulīkato saññā vedayita nirodhe ca ānisasaḥ anadhigato saḥ ca me anāsevito
translated: ‘I have not seen the danger in the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception and have not developed it, and I have not attained the distinction of the cessation of perception and feeling and have not cultivated it.

original: Tasmā me saññāvedayitanirodhe cittaṁ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etaṁ santanti passato’.
analyzed: tasmā me saññā vedayita nirodhe cittam na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etam santanti passato
translated: So my mind did not launch out upon it, nor become placid, settled, and resolute, when I considered the stilling of thought and examination.

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, etadahosi:🔽‘sace kho ahaṁ nevasaññānāsaññāyatane ādīnavaṁ disvā taṁ bahulaṁ kareyyaṁ, saññāvedayitanirodhe
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda etat ahosi  sace kho aham na ivasaññā nāsañña āyatane ādīnavam disvā tam bahulam kareyya saññā vedayita nirodhe
translated: I considered thus:

original: ānisaṁsaṁ adhigamma tamāseveyyaṁ, ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ vijjati yaṁ me saññāvedayitanirodhe
analyzed: ānisasam adhigamma tam āseveyya ṭhānam kho pana itam vijjati yam me saññā vedayita nirodhe
translated: ‘If I see danger in the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception and frequently dwell on that danger, and if I see benefit in the stilling of thought and examination and frequently dwell on that benefit, it is possible that my mind will launch out upon the stilling of thought and examination,

original: cittaṁ pakkhandeyya pasīdeyya santiṭṭheyya vimucceyya etaṁ santanti passato’.
analyzed: cittam pakkhandeyya pasīdeyya santiṭṭheyya vimucceyya etam santanti passato
translated: will become placid, settled, and resolute, when I consider the stilling of thought and examination.’

original: So kho ahaṁ, ānanda, aparena samayena nevasaññānāsaññāyatane ādīnavaṁ disvā taṁ bahulamakāsiṁ, saññāvedayitanirodhe ānisaṁsaṁ adhigamma tamāseviṁ.
analyzed: saḥ kho aha ānanda aparena samayena nevasaññā nāsañña āyatane ādīnavam disvā tam bahulam akāsi saññā vedayita nirodhe ānisasam adhigamma tam āsevi
translated: “Then, Ananda, after some time I saw danger in the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception and frequently dwelled on that danger, and I saw benefit in the stilling of thought and examination and frequently dwelled on that benefit.🔽So my mind launched out upon the stilling of thought and examination,

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, saññāvedayitanirodhe cittaṁ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati etaṁ santanti passato.
analyzed: tassa mayhaḥ ānanda saññā vedayita nirodhe cittam pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati etam santanti passato
translated: became placid, settled, and resolute, when I considered the stilling of thought and examination.

original: So kho ahaṁ, ānanda, sabbaso nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṁ samatikkamma saññāvedayitanirodhaṁ upasampajja viharāmi, paññāya ca me disvā āsavā parikkhayaṁ agamaṁsu.
analyzed: saḥ kho aha ānanda sabbaso nevasaññā nāsañña āyatanam samatikkamma saññā vedayita nirodham upasampajja viharāmi paññāya ca me disvā āsavā parikkhayam agamasu
translated: I entered and dwelled in the cessation of perception and feeling, and my taints were destroyed by directly knowing and fully understanding with wisdom.

original: Yāvakīvañcāhaṁ, ānanda, imā nava anupubbavihārasamāpattiyo na evaṁ anulomapaṭilomaṁ🔽samāpajjimpi vuṭṭhahimpi, neva tāvāhaṁ, ānanda, sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake
analyzed: ānanda imāḥ nava anupubba vihāra samāpattiyaḥ na evam anuloma paṭiloma  samāpajjimpi vuṭṭhahimpi na iva tāva āha ānanda sa devake loke sa mārake sa brahmake
translated: As long as I did not directly know and fully understand the nine successive abidings in this way, forwards and backwards,

original: sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya ‘anuttaraṁ sammāsambodhiṁ abhisambuddho’ti paccaññāsiṁ.
analyzed: sa samaṇa brāhmaṇiyā pajāya sa deva manussāya anuttaram sammāsambodhim abhisambuddho ti paccaññāsi
translated: I did not claim to have awakened to the unsurpassed perfect enlightenment in this world with its gods, lords of death, and supreme beings, in this society with its monastics and brahmins, its gods and humans.

original: Yato ca kho ahaṁ, ānanda, imā nava anupubbavihārasamāpattiyo evaṁ anulomapaṭilomaṁ🔽samāpajjimpi vuṭṭhahimpi, athāhaṁ, ānanda, sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā
analyzed: yatas ca kho aha ānanda imāḥ nava anupubba vihāra samāpattiyaḥ evam anuloma paṭiloma  atha āha ānanda sa devake loke sa mārake sa brahmake sa ssamaṇa brāhmaṇiyā
translated: But when I directly knew and fully understood the nine successive abidings in this way, forwards and backwards,

original: pajāya sadevamanussāya ‘anuttaraṁ sammāsambodhiṁ abhisambuddho’ti paccaññāsiṁ.
analyzed: pajāya sa deva manussāya anuttaram sammāsambodhim abhisambuddhaḥ iti paccaññā asi
translated: then I claimed to have awakened to the unsurpassed perfect enlightenment in this world with its gods, lords of death, and supreme beings, in this society with its monastics and brahmins, its gods and humans.

original: Ñāṇañca pana me dassanaṁ udapādi:
analyzed: ñāṇam ca pana me dassanam udapādi
translated: And knowledge & vision arose in me:

original: ‘akuppā me cetovimutti, ayamantimā jāti, natthi dāni punabbhavo’”ti.
analyzed: akuppā me cetaḥ vimutti ayam antimā jāti natthi dāni punabbhavoti
translated: ‘Unprovoked is my liberation of mind. This is my last birth. There is now no further becoming.’“

original: Dasamaṁ.🔽Mahāvaggo catuttho.
analyzed: dasama  mahāvaggo catuttho
translated: The tenth.🔽The fourth great section.

original: Tassuddānaṁ
analyzed: tassa uddāna
translated: The summary:

original: Dve vihārā ca nibbānaṁ,
analyzed: dve vihārā ca nibbāna
translated: Two dwellings, and Nibbāna,

original: gāvī jhānena pañcamaṁ;
analyzed: gāvī jhānena pañcama
translated: an ox, and the fifth, jhāna;

original: Ānando brāhmaṇā devo,
analyzed: ānandaḥ brāhmaṇāḥ
translated: Ānanda, a brahman, a god,

original: nāgena tapussena cāti.
analyzed: nāgena tapussena ca ati
translated: an nāga, and Tapussa.

original: Aṅguttara Nikāya 9.42
analyzed: aṅguttara nikāya
translated: The Book of the Tens

original: 5. Sāmaññavagga
analyzed: sāmañña vagga
translated: The Lesser Chapter

original: Sambādhasutta
analyzed: sambādha sutta
translated: The Narrow Passage

original: Ekaṁ samayaṁ āyasmā ānando kosambiyaṁ viharati ghositārāme.
analyzed: ekam samayam āyasmai ānandaḥ kosambiyam viharati ghosita ārāme
translated: At one time the Venerable Ānanda was dwelling at Kosambī in Ghosita’s Park.

original: Atha kho āyasmā udāyī yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā ānandena saddhiṁ sammodi.
analyzed: atha khalu āyasmai udāyī yena āyasmai ānandaḥ tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā ānandena saddhim sammodi
translated: Then the Venerable Udāyī approached the Venerable Ānanda and exchanged greetings with him.

original: Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho āyasmā udāyī āyasmantaṁ ānandaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: sammodanīyam katham sāraṇīyam vītisāretvā ekamantam nisīdi ekamantam nisinnaḥ kho āyasmai udāyī āyasmantam ānandam etat avoca
translated: When they had concluded their greetings and cordial talk, he sat down to one side and said to the Venerable Ānanda:

original: “vuttamidaṁ, āvuso, pañcālacaṇḍena devaputtena:🔽‘Sambādhe gataṁ okāsaṁ,🔽Avidvā bhūrimedhaso;
analyzed: vuttam idam āvuso pañcālacaṇḍena deva puttena  sambādhe gatam okāsa  a vidvān bhūri medhasaḥ
translated: “Friend Ānanda, the deity Pañcālacaṇḍā has declared:

original: Yo jhānamabujjhi buddho,
analyzed: yaḥ jhānam abujjhi buddhaḥ
translated: “The Buddha, who is skilled in the narrow passage,🔽has discovered the jhāna that is free from the narrow passage.

original: Paṭilīnanisabho munī’ti.
analyzed: paṭilīna nisabhaḥ muni iti
translated: The Sage has gone to the open, free from the thicket.’

original: Katamo, āvuso, sambādho, katamo sambādhe okāsādhigamo vutto bhagavatā”ti?
analyzed: katamaḥ āvuso sambādhaḥ katamaḥ sambādhe okāsa adhigamaḥ vutto bhagavatā ati
translated: “What, friend, is the thicket, and what is the opening in the thicket spoken of by the Blessed One?”

original: “Pañcime, āvuso, kāmaguṇā sambādho vutto bhagavatā.
analyzed: pañcime āvuso kāma guṇāḥ sambādhaḥ vuttaḥ bhagavatā
translated: “Friend, the Blessed One has said that the five cords of sensual pleasure are the thicket, the wilderness, the thorny brake, bound up with lust and desire, smeared with filth, stinking, and disgusting, and a hindrance to attaining the unsurpassed security from bondage.

original: Katame pañca?
analyzed: katame pañca
translated: What are the five?

original: Cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṁhitā rajanīyā,🔽sotaviññeyyā saddā …pe…🔽ghānaviññeyyā gandhā …
analyzed: cakkhu viññeyyā rūpā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piya rūpā kāma upasahitā rajanīyā  sota viññeyyā saddāḥ pe  ghāna viññeyyāḥ gandhāḥ
translated: Forms cognizable by the eye that are wished for, desired, agreeable, and likeable, connected with sensual desire and provocative of lust.🔽Sounds cognizable by the ear…🔽Odours cognizable by the nose…

original: jivhāviññeyyā rasā …
analyzed: jivhā viññeyyāḥ rasāḥ
translated: Flavours cognizable by the tongue…

original: kāyaviññeyyā phoṭṭhabbā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṁhitā rajanīyā.
analyzed: kāya viññeyyā phoṭṭhabbā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piya rūpā kāma upasahitā rajanīyā
translated: Tangibles cognizable by the body that are wished for, desired, agreeable, and likeable, connected with sensual desire and provocative of lust.

original: Ime kho, āvuso, pañca kāmaguṇā sambādho vutto bhagavatā.
analyzed: ime kho āvuso pañca kāmaguṇā sambādhaḥ vuttaḥ bhagavatā
translated: Friend, the Blessed One has said that these five cords of sensual pleasure are the thicket, the wilderness, the thorny brake, bound up with lust and desire, smeared with filth, stinking, and disgusting, and a hindrance to attaining the unsurpassed security from bondage.

original: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi …pe… paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: idha āvuso bhikkhu vivicca iva kāmehi pe paṭhamam jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: “Here, friend, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unwholesome states, a bhikkhu enters upon and abides in the first jhana, which is accompanied by applied and sustained thought, with rapture and pleasure born of seclusion.

original: Ettāvatāpi kho, āvuso, sambādhe okāsādhigamo vutto bhagavatā pariyāyena.
analyzed: ettāvatā api khalu āvuso sambādhe okāsa adhigamaḥ vuttaḥ bhagavatā pariyāyena
translated: To this extent the Blessed One has spoken of the opening in the thicket by implication.

original: Tatrāpatthi sambādho.
analyzed: tatra apatthi sambādhaḥ
translated: But here there is a thicket too.

original: Kiñca tattha sambādho?
analyzed: kiñca tattha sambādho
translated: And what is the thicket here?

original: Yadeva tattha vitakkavicārā aniruddhā honti, ayamettha sambādho.
analyzed: yat eva tattha vitakka vicārāḥ a niruddhāḥ honti ayam ettha sambādhaḥ
translated: It is any desire, lust, delight, craving, attraction, cleaving, and mental fixation there in that state.

original: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā …pe… dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: puna caparaḥ āvuso bhikkhu vitakka vicārānam vūpasamā pe dutiyam jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: “And further, with the stilling of applied and sustained thought, a bhikkhu enters upon and abides in the second jhana…

original: Ettāvatāpi kho, āvuso, sambādhe okāsādhigamo vutto bhagavatā pariyāyena.
analyzed: ettāvatā api khalu āvuso sambādhe okāsa adhigamaḥ vuttaḥ bhagavatā pariyāyena
translated: To this extent the Blessed One has stated the matter of an opening in the open by way of a simile.

original: Tatrāpatthi sambādho.
analyzed: tatra apatthi sambādhaḥ
translated: But there is a closed-in place here.

original: Kiñca tattha sambādho?
analyzed: kiñca tattha sambādho
translated: And what is the closed-in place here?

original: Yadeva tattha pīti aniruddhā hoti, ayamettha sambādho.
analyzed: yat eva tattha aniruddhā hoti ayam ettha sambādhaḥ
translated: Whatever delight there is there, that is the closed-in place here.

original: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu pītiyā ca virāgā …pe… tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: puna caparaḥ āvuso bhikkhu pītiyā ca virāgā pe tatiyam jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: “And further, with the fading away as well of rapture, a bhikkhu… enters upon and abides in the third jhana…

original: Ettāvatāpi kho, āvuso, sambādhe okāsādhigamo vutto bhagavatā pariyāyena.
analyzed: ettāvatā api khalu āvuso sambādhe okāsa adhigamaḥ vuttaḥ bhagavatā pariyāyena
translated: To this extent the Blessed One has stated the matter of an opening in the open by way of a simile.

original: Tatrāpatthi sambādho.
analyzed: tatra apatthi sambādhaḥ
translated: But there is a closed-in place here.

original: Kiñca tattha sambādho?
analyzed: kiñca tattha sambādho
translated: And what is the closed-in place here?

original: Yadeva tattha upekkhāsukhaṁ aniruddhaṁ hoti, ayamettha sambādho.
analyzed: yat eva tattha upekkhā sukham a niruddham hoti ayam ettha sambādhaḥ
translated: Whatever equanimity there is there, that is the closed-in place here.

original: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā …pe… catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: puna caparaḥ āvuso bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā pe catuttham jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: “And further, with the abandoning of pleasure and pain… a bhikkhu enters upon and abides in the fourth jhana…

original: Ettāvatāpi kho, āvuso, sambādhe okāsādhigamo vutto bhagavatā pariyāyena.
analyzed: ettāvatā api khalu āvuso sambādhe okāsa adhigamaḥ vuttaḥ bhagavatā pariyāyena
translated: In this way, too, a passage referring to an open space in a confined place has been stated by the Blessed One in terms of a simile.

original: Tatrāpatthi sambādho.
analyzed: tatra apatthi sambādhaḥ
translated: But there is a confined place here.

original: Kiñca tattha sambādho?
analyzed: kiñca tattha sambādho
translated: And what is the confined place here?

original: Yadeva tattha rūpasaññā aniruddhā hoti, ayamettha sambādho.
analyzed: yat eva tattha rūpa saññā a niruddhā hoti ayam ettha sambādhaḥ
translated: It is any perception of form that has not been abandoned in this way. This is the confined place here.

original: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu sabbaso rūpasaññānaṁ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṁ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṁ amanasikārā ‘ananto ākāso’ti ākāsānañcāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: puna caparaḥ āvuso bhikkhu sabbaso rūpa saññānam samatikkamā paṭigha saññānam atthaṅgamā nānatta saññānam amanasikārā anantaḥ ākāsaḥ ti ākāsānañcāyatanam upasampajja viharati
translated: “Again, with the complete surmounting of perceptions of form, with the disappearance of perceptions of sensory impact, with non-attention to perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite,’ a bhikkhu enters and dwells in the base of the infinity of space.

original: Ettāvatāpi kho, āvuso, sambādhe okāsādhigamo vutto bhagavatā pariyāyena.
analyzed: ettāvatā api khalu āvuso sambādhe okāsa adhigamaḥ vuttaḥ bhagavatā pariyāyena
translated: In this way, too, a passage referring to an open space in a confined place has been stated by the Blessed One in terms of a simile.

original: Tatrāpatthi sambādho.
analyzed: tatra apatthi sambādhaḥ
translated: But there is a confined place here.

original: Kiñca tattha sambādho?
analyzed: kiñca tattha sambādho
translated: And what is the confined place here?

original: Yadeva tattha ākāsānañcāyatanasaññā aniruddhā hoti, ayamettha sambādho.
